species[[Antennaria aromatica]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 394, 409, 410, 411, 415 |treatment_page=page 408 }}Dioecious. Plants 2–7 cm (stems stipitate-glandular). Stolons 0.5–2.5 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, usually cuneate-spatulate, sometimes oblanceolate, 5–16 × 3–10 mm, tips mucronate, faces gray-pubescent (and stipitate-glandular; fresh leaves citronella scented). Cauline leaves linear, 3–14 mm, not flagged (apices acute). Heads borne singly or 2–5 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4.5–6.5 mm; pistillate 5–7(–9) mm. Phyllaries distally light brown, dark brown, or olivaceous. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3 mm; pistillate 3.5–4.5 mm. Cypselae 0.9–2 mm, sparingly papillate; pappi: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 4.5–5.5 mm. 2n = 28, 56, 84.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer. |habitat=Subalpine limestone talus |elevation=1600–3000 m |distribution=Alta.;Idaho;Mont.;Wyo. |discussion=

Known only from the northern Rockies, Antennaria aromatica is characterized by glandulosity, cuneate leaves, and odor of citronella in crushed leaves of living material. It is most closely related to A. densifolia of the Northwest Territories and Yukon (R. J. Bayer 1989c). Some collections of pistillate plants from Colorado and other areas of the Rockies superficially resemble A. aromatica and undoubtedly have A. aromatica in their parentage. They are non-glandular and odorless and are closer to the type of A. pulvinata, which is included in the circumscription of A. rosea, as A. rosea subsp. pulvinata (Bayer). Antennaria aromatica is a sexual progenitor of the A. rosea and A. alpina polyploid complexes.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria aromatica |authority=Evert |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid summer. |habitat=Subalpine limestone talus |elevation=1600–3000 m |distribution=Alta.;Idaho;Mont.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Madroño |publication year=1984 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_661.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria aromatica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria corymbosa |accepted_authority=E. E. Nelson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bot. Gaz. |place=27: 212. 1899 |year=1899 }} |common_names=Flat-top or meadow pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria acuta |authority=Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria dioica var. corymbosa |authority=(E. E. Nelson) Jepson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria hygrophila |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria nardina |authority=Greene |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria corymbosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria corymbosa]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 393, 396, 409, 410, 415 |treatment_page=page 407 }}Dioecious. Plants 6–15 cm. Stolons 1–10 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate, 18–45 × 2–4 mm, tips mucronate, faces ± gray-tomentose. Cauline leaves linear, 8–13 mm, not flagged (apices acuminate). Heads 3–7 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4–5.3 mm; pistillate 4–5 mm. Phyllaries (bases each with distinct dark brown or blackish spot) distally white or light brown. Corollas: staminate 2–3.2 mm; pistillate 2.5–3.5 mm. Cypselae 0.5–1 mm, slightly papillate; pappi: staminate 2.5–3.5 mm; pistillate 3.5–4.5 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early–mid summer. |habitat=Moist subalpine-alpine willow thickets in the Rocky and Cascade mountains, the Sierra Nevada and mountains of the Great Basin |elevation=1900–3500 m |distribution=Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Antennaria corymbosa is characterized by linear-oblanceolate basal leaves and white-tipped phyllaries, each with a distinct black spot near the base of the scarious portion. A form with black phyllaries (A. acuta) occurs sporadically throughout the range of the species (R. J. Bayer 1988). Antennaria corymbosa is a sexual progenitor of the A. rosea complex.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria corymbosa |authority=E. E. Nelson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Antennaria acuta;Antennaria dioica var. corymbosa;Antennaria hygrophila;Antennaria nardina |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering early–mid summer. |habitat=Moist subalpine-alpine willow thickets in the Rocky and Cascade mountains, the Sierra Nevada and mountains of the Great Basin |elevation=1900–3500 m |distribution=Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Bot. Gaz. |publication year=1899 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_656.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria corymbosa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria densifolia |accepted_authority=A. E. Porsild |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Natl. Mus. Canada |place=101: 26. 1945 |year=1945 }} |common_names=Denseleaf pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria ellyae |authority=A. E. Porsild |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria densifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria densifolia]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 394, 408, 413, 415 |treatment_page=page 411 }}Dioecious. Plants 3.5–16 cm. Stolons 1–2 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate to cuneate, 3–7 × 2–5 mm, tips mucronate, faces gray-tomentose. Cauline leaves linear, 2–13 mm, distal flagged. Heads 2–5 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 3–6.5 mm; pistillate 4.5–7.5 mm. Pistillate involucres 4.5–7.5 mm. Phyllaries distally light brown, dark brown, or black. Corollas: staminate 2–3.5 mm; pistillate 2.5–4.5 mm. Cypselae 0.8–1.5 mm, glabrous; pappi: staminate 2.5–3.5 mm; pistillate 2.5–3.5 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Subalpine-alpine limestone talus |elevation=700–2800 m |distribution=B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont. |discussion=

Antennaria densifolia is found on limestone talus below treeline in the MacKenzie, Richardson, and Ogilvie mountains of the District of MacKenzie and Yukon Territory and in Granite County, Montana (R. J. Bayer 1989c). It differs from A. aromatica in being non-glandular and in other characters. Herbarium specimens (in DAO) from British Columbia that morphologically appear to be a strictly gynoecious form of A. densifolia may be apomicts related to A. alpina that are derived from A. densifolia, a sexual progenitor of the complex.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria densifolia |authority=A. E. Porsild |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Antennaria ellyae |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Subalpine-alpine limestone talus |elevation=700–2800 m |distribution=B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont. |reference=None |publication title=Bull. Natl. Mus. Canada |publication year=1945 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_670.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria densifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria dimorpha |accepted_authority=(Nuttall) Torrey & A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. N. Amer. |place=2: 431. 1843 |year=1843 }} |common_names=Low or two-form or cushion pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Gnaphalium dimorphum |authority=Nuttall |rank=species |publication_title=Trans. Amer. Philos. Soc., n. s. |publication_place=7: 405. 1841 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria dimorpha var. integra |authority=L. F. Henderson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria dimorpha var. macrocephala |authority=D. C. Eaton |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria dimorpha var. nuttallii |authority=D. C. Eaton |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria latisquama |authority= |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria macrocephala |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria dimorpha |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria dimorpha]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 389, 393, 399 |treatment_page=page 398 }}Dioecious. Plants 0.5–4 cm. Stolons none. Basal leaves: 1-nerved, linear to narrowly spatulate, 8–11 × 1–1.2 mm, tips acute, faces ± gray-tomentose. Cauline leaves linear or oblanceolate, 7–12 mm, not flagged (apices acute). Heads borne singly. Involucres: staminate 6–8 mm; pistillate 10–11 mm. Phyllaries distally dingy brown (apices acute-acuminate). Corollas: staminate 3–5 mm; pistillate 8–10 mm. Cypselae 2–3.5 mm, pubescent; pappi: staminate 4.5–6 mm; pistillate 10–12 mm. 2n = 28, 56.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early–mid spring. |habitat=Sagebrush steppe, plains, foothills of mountains |elevation=600–3400 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Sask.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Antennaria dimorpha is characterized by narrowly oblanceolate leaves and relatively large heads (borne singly). It is, perhaps, the most xerophytic of spring-blooming Antennaria species. It belongs to the Dimorphae group.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria dimorpha |authority=(Nuttall) Torrey & A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Antennaria dimorpha var. integra;Antennaria dimorpha var. macrocephala;Antennaria dimorpha var. nuttallii;Antennaria latisquama;Antennaria macrocephala |basionyms=Gnaphalium dimorphum |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering early–mid spring. |habitat=Sagebrush steppe, plains, foothills of mountains |elevation=600–3400 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Sask.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Fl. N. Amer. |publication year=1843 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_633.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria dimorpha }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria dioica |accepted_authority=(Linnaeus) Gaertner |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fruct. Sem. Pl. |place=2: 410. 1791 |year=1791 }} |common_names=Stoloniferous pussytoes |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Gnaphalium dioicum |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |publication_title=Sp. Pl. |publication_place=2: 850. 1753 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria hyperborea |authority=D. Don |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria insularis |authority=Greene |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria dioica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria dioica]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 389, 390, 395 |treatment_page=page 406 }}Dioecious. Plants 3–10 cm. Stolons 2–5 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate or rhombic-spatulate, 3–18 × 3–6 mm, tips mucronate, abaxial faces gray-tomentose, adaxial green-glabrous. Cauline leaves linear, 7–13 mm, not flagged (apices acute). Heads 3–7 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 5–6.5 mm; pistillate 5–7 mm. Phyllaries distally dark pink to light pink or white. Corollas: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 4–5 mm. Cypselae 0.5–1 mm, papillate; pappi: staminate 3.5–4.5 mm; pistillate 5–6 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Dry slopes on tundra |elevation=0–600 m |distribution=Alaska (Aleutian Islands);Eurasia. |discussion=

Antennaria dioica ranges from the British Isles to Japan and into the Aleutian Islands (R. J. Bayer 2000). It is characterized by glabrous adaxial leaf faces and distally pink or white phyllaries. The circumscription of A. dioica in North America has long been debated; A. marginata of southwestern states bears a remarkable similarity to A. dioica. DNA sequence data (Bayer et al. 1996) indicate that the two taxa are not sisters; they are only distantly related. They are allopatric. Antennaria dioica may be a sexual progenitor of the A. parvifolia complex.

Sem. Pl. |publication year=1791 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_654.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria dioica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria flagellaris |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=17: 212. 1882 |year=1882 }} |common_names=Whip or stoloniferous pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria dimorpha var. flagellaris |authority=A. Gray |rank=variety |publication_title=in C. Wilkes et al., U.S. Expl. Exped. |publication_place=17: 366. 1874 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria flagellaris |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria flagellaris]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 389, 393 |treatment_page=page 399 }}Dioecious. Plants 0.5–1.5 cm. Stolons 3–10 cm (leafless except tips, relatively slender). Basal leaves 1-nerved, linear-oblanceolate, 16–18 × 1.5–2 mm, tips acute, faces ± gray-tomentose. Cauline leaves linear or oblanceolate, 7–15 mm, not flagged. Heads borne singly. Involucres: staminate 6–7 mm; pistillate 7–9 mm. Phyllaries (relatively wide) distally brown to blackish or whitish. Corollas: staminate 3–4.5 mm; pistillate 5–7 mm. Cypselae 2–3 mm, papillate; pappi: staminate 3.5–4.5 mm; pistillate 6–8 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid–late spring. |habitat=Seasonally dry basins in foothills of mountains, often associated with sagebrush flats |elevation=900–2700 m |distribution=B.C.;Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Antennaria flagellaris is among the more distinctive species of Antennaria, with its flagelliform stolons (whiplike with leaves only at the very end) and heads borne singly. It belongs to the Dimorphae group (R. J. Bayer 1990; Bayer et al. 1996).

Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Antennaria dimorpha var. flagellaris |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mid–late spring. |habitat=Seasonally dry basins in foothills of mountains, often associated with sagebrush flats |elevation=900–2700 m |distribution=B.C.;Calif.;Idaho;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication year=1882 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_634.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria flagellaris }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

revision.comment: Fixed italics in discussion
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria friesiana |accepted_authority=(Trautvetter) E. Ekman |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Svensk Bot. Tidskr. |place=22: 416. 1928 |year=1928 }} |common_names=Fries’s pussytoes;antennaire de Fries |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria alpina var. friesiana |authority=Trautvetter |rank=variety |publication_title=Trudy Imp. S.-Petersburgsk. Bot. Sada |publication_place=6: 24. 1879 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria friesiana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria friesiana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 392, 393, 395, 413, 414 |treatment_page=page 412 }}Dioecious or gynoecious (staminate plants uncommon or in equal frequencies to pistillates, respectively). Plants 7–15 cm (stems stipitate-glandular, hairs purple). Stolons 0.1–4 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, narrowly spatulate to oblanceolate, 11–30 × 2–4 mm, tips mucronate, abaxial faces tomentose, adaxial green-glabrescent to gray-pubescent. Cauline leaves linear, 4–20 mm, flagged. Heads 2–6 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4–6.5 mm; pistillate 5.5–8 mm. Phyllaries distally usually black, light brown, dark brown, or olivaceous, sometimes. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3 mm; pistillate 3–4.5 mm. Cypselae 1.2–2 mm, glabrous or slightly papillate; pappi: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 3.5–5 mm. 2n = 28, 56, 63, 100+.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=N.W.T.;Nfld. and Labr.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Arctic North America;arctic Siberia. |discussion=

Subspecies 3 (3 in the flora).

The Antennaria friesiana complex consists of subsp. alaskana, subsp. neoalaskana, and subsp. friesiana, the former two are dioecious (sexual) phases of the latter gynoecious (asexual) form. The sexual populations are known from Alaska and cordilleran areas of northern Yukon and adjacent Northwest Territories (R. J. Bayer 1991). The apomictic phase is almost circumpolar, occurring from the central and eastern Siberian plateau eastward across the North American arctic to Greenland (Bayer). E. Hultén (1968) circumscribed a fourth subspecies, A. friesiana subsp. compacta. After studying its morphology, in the field and herbarium, it is apparent that Hultén’s taxon contains at least three incongruous entities that are probably not at all related to the other two subspecies of A. friesiana. Hultén’s subsp. compacta included A. densifolia, which is recognized as a distinct species, and A. crymophila and A. neoalaskana as taxonomic synonyms. Antennaria compacta in the strict sense and A. crymophila are perhaps hybrid apomicts and are treated here in A. alpina (see Bayer for details). Antennaria neoalaskana is treated here as a subspecies of A. friesiana.

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Stolons 1–4 cm (usually prostrate, sometimes ascending, usually rooting at tips, plants forming mats); involucres: pistillate 7–8 mm |[[Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana|Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Stolons 0.5–1 cm (erect, usually not rooting at tips, plants not forming mats); involucres: pistillate 5.5–7 mm |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Plants gynoecious (staminates unknown) |[[Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana|Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Plants dioecious (staminates and pistillates in equal frequencies in populations) |[[Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana|Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria friesiana |authority=(Trautvetter) E. Ekman |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Antennaria alpina var. friesiana |family=Asteraceae |distribution=N.W.T.;Nfld. and Labr.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Arctic North America;arctic Siberia. |reference=None |publication title=Svensk Bot. Tidskr. |publication year=1928 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_674.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria friesiana }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Antennaria]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana |accepted_authority=(Malte) Hultén |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Ark. Bot., n. s. |place=7: 134. 1968 |year=1968 }} |common_names=Alaskan pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria alaskana |authority=Malte |rank=species |publication_title=Rhodora |publication_place=36: 107. 1934 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria friesiana var. beringensis |authority=Hultén |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria friesiana;Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria friesiana]]
subspecies[[Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 414, 415 |treatment_page=page 413 }}Dioecious (staminates and pistillates in equal frequencies in populations). Plants 7.5–14 cm. Stolons 0.5–1 cm. Cauline leaves 4–20 mm. Heads 2–6. Involucres: staminate 4–6.5 mm; pistillate 5.5–7 mm. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3 mm; pistillate 3–4.5 mm. Cypselae 1.2–1.8 mm; pappi: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 3.5–5 mm. 2n = 28, 56.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, on or near dry rocky outcrops or sand ridges |elevation=500–1500 m |distribution=N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska. |discussion=

Subspecies alaskana is dioecious (sexual) and known from Alaska and cordilleran areas of northern Yukon and adjacent Northwest Territories (R. J. Bayer 1991, 1993). It is a probable progenitor of the Antennaria alpina complex.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana |authority=(Malte) Hultén |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Antennaria friesiana var. beringensis |basionyms=Antennaria alaskana |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, on or near dry rocky outcrops or sand ridges |elevation=500–1500 m |distribution=N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska. |reference=None |publication title=Ark. Bot., n. s. |publication year=1968 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_675.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria friesiana |subspecies=Antennaria friesiana subsp. alaskana }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria friesiana]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana |accepted_authority= |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria angustifolia |authority=E. Ekman |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria ekmaniana |authority=A. E. Porsild |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria friesiana;Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria friesiana]]
subspecies[[Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 413 |treatment_page=page 414 }}Gynoecious (staminates unknown). Plants 3.5–12.5 cm. Stolons 0.5–1 cm. Cauline leaves 7–14 mm. Heads 2–4. Involucres: staminate unknown; pistillate 6–7 mm. Corollas staminate unknown; pistillate 3.5–4 mm. Cypselae 1–2 mm; pappi: staminate unknown; pistillate 4–4.5 mm. 2n = 56, 63, 100+.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, on or near dry rocky outcrops or sand ridges |elevation=100–1500 m |distribution=Greenland;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);N.W.T.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Siberia (arctic). |discussion=

The sexual progenitors of subsp. friesiana are subspp. alaskana and neoalaskana.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Antennaria angustifolia;Antennaria ekmaniana |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, on or near dry rocky outcrops or sand ridges |elevation=100–1500 m |distribution=Greenland;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);N.W.T.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Siberia (arctic). |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_676.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria friesiana |subspecies=Antennaria friesiana subsp. friesiana }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria friesiana]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana |accepted_authority=(A. E. Porsild) R. J. Bayer & Stebbins |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Canad. J. Bot. |place=71: 1596. 1993 |year=1993 }} |common_names=Frost boil or outcrop pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria neoalaskana |authority=A. E. Porsild |rank=species |publication_title=Sargentia |publication_place=4: 71. 1943 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria friesiana;Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria friesiana]]
subspecies[[Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 413, 415 |treatment_page=page 414 }}Dioecious (staminates and pistillates in equal frequencies in populations). Plants 7.5–14 cm. Stolons 1–4 cm. Cauline leaves 4–20 mm. Heads 2–6. Involucres: staminate 4–6.5 mm; pistillate 7–8 mm. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3 mm; pistillate 3–4.5 mm. Cypselae 1.2–1.8 mm; pappi: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 3.5–5 mm. 2n = 56.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, on dry rocky outcrops, fell fields, or gravelly frost boils |elevation=600–1500 m |distribution=N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska. |discussion=

Subspecies neoalaskana is dioecious (sexual) and occurs from the eastern Brooks Range, Alaska, to the Richardson Mountains and into the central MacKenzie Mountains, on the Yukon-Northwest Territories boundary (R. J. Bayer 1993). It intergrades somewhat with the other two subspecies of Antennaria friesiana; it can be separated from other arctic members of Antennaria because it is dioecious and has 2–6 heads and well-developed stolons. It is a likely progenitor of the A. alpina complex.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana |authority=(A. E. Porsild) R. J. Bayer & Stebbins |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Antennaria neoalaskana |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Arctic and alpine tundra, on dry rocky outcrops, fell fields, or gravelly frost boils |elevation=600–1500 m |distribution=N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska. |reference=None |publication title=Canad. J. Bot. |publication year=1993 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_677.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria friesiana |subspecies=Antennaria friesiana subsp. neoalaskana }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria friesiana]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria geyeri |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Amer. Acad. Arts, n. s. |place=4: 107. 1849 |year=1849 }} |common_names=Pinewoods pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria geyeri |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria geyeri]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 59, 386, 389, 394 |treatment_page=page 396 }}Dioecious. Plants 3–14 cm (bases woody). Stolons none. Basal leaves absent at flowering. Cauline leaves linear-lanceolate to cuneate-oblanceolate, 11–35 × 2–6 imm, acute, not flagged (apices acute), faces gray-pubescent. Heads 3–25 in corymbiform to paniculiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 6–8 mm; pistillate 6–8 mm. Phyllaries distally red to pink, light brown, or white. Corollas: staminate 3–4.5 mm; pistillate 5–6 mm. Cypselae 2–2.5 mm, pubescent and papillate; pappi: staminate 6–7 mm (capillary); pistillate 6–7 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Dry lower montane to montane coniferous forests, usually in ± thick duff under Pinus ponderosa |elevation=600–2400 m |distribution=Calif.;Nev.;Oreg.;Wash. |discussion=

Antennaria geyeri is distinctive because it has woody upright branches and is not stoloniferous. It lacks basal leaves at flowering and has heads that are often described as subdioecious (central flowers are often bisexual). As the only member of the Geyerae group, A. geyeri is not closely related to any other species of Antennaria; it bears strong similarities to some species of Anaphalis (R. J. Bayer 1990; Bayer et al. 1996).

Amer. Acad. Arts, n. s. |publication year=1849 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_626.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria geyeri }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria howellii |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=3: 174. 1897 |year=1897 }} |common_names=Howell’s pussytoes;antennaire de Howell |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta subsp. howellii |authority=(Greene) Hultén |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. neglecta var. howellii |authority=(Greene) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. neodioica subsp. howellii |authority=(Greene) R. J. Bayer |rank=subspecies }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria howellii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria howellii]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 395, 401, 402, 404, 405, 406 |treatment_page=page 403 }}Gynoecious (staminate plants very uncommon). Plants (6–)8–35 cm (stems sometimes stipitate-glandular). Stolons 1–9(–12) cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate to oblanceolate, spatulate-obovate, narrowly to broadly ovate, or cuneate-oblanceolate, 20–48(–65) × 2.5–20 mm, tips mucronate, faces abaxially tomentose, adaxially green-glabrous or gray-pubescent. Cauline leaves linear, 8–40 mm, distal sometimes flagged (apices acute). Heads 3–15 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 6–6.5 mm; pistillate 6–11 mm. Phyllaries (bases sometimes rose) distally white, cream, or light brown. Corollas: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 3.5–6.5(–8) mm. Cypselae 0.8–2 mm, ± papillate; pappi: staminate 4–4.5 mm; pistillate 5.5–9 mm. 2n = 56, 84, 140 (under A. neodioica).{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;N.S.;N.W.T.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Mont.;N.C.;N.Dak.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Ohio;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Utah;Va.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies 4 (4 in the flora).

The Antennaria howellii (previously A. neodioica) polyploid complex is highly variable morphologically; four more or less distinct subspecies can be recognized within it. The sexual progenitors of the complex are A. neglecta, A. plantaginifolia, A. racemosa, and A. virginica (see R. J. Bayer 1985). Antennaria marginata may also be a minor contributor to the origins of the complex. A. Cronquist (H. A. Gleason and Cronquist 1991) included members of this complex in A. neglecta; I maintain, because these apomicts are of hybrid polyploid origin from among multiple sexual progenitors, they best not be included within the circumscription of any one sexual progenitor (Bayer 1989d).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Basal leaves green-glabrous adaxially |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Basal leaves pubescent adaxially (sometimes glabrescent with age) |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Basal leaves 1-nerved, 20–40 × 6–9 mm; distal cauline leaves flagged; phyllaries distally white or cream |[[Antennaria howellii subsp. canadensis|Antennaria howellii subsp. canadensis]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Basal leaves 1–3-nerved, 25–40 × 9–12 mm; distal cauline leaves not flagged; phyllaries distally light brown or white |[[Antennaria howellii subsp. howellii|Antennaria howellii subsp. howellii]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Basal leaves spatulate to narrowly or broadly obovate (petiolate); stolons 3–8(–12) cm (leaves along stolons almost equal to those in rosettes at ends) |[[Antennaria howellii subsp. neodioica|Antennaria howellii subsp. neodioica]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Basal leaves cuneate-oblanceolate, spatulate, or spatulate-obovate (without distinct petioles); stolons 4–9 cm (leaves along stolons smaller than in rosettes at ends) |[[Antennaria howellii subsp. petaloidea|Antennaria howellii subsp. petaloidea]] |}

(Nfld.);Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Mont.;N.C.;N.Dak.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Ohio;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Utah;Va.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Pittonia |publication year=1897 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_648.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria howellii }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Antennaria]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria howellii subsp. canadensis |accepted_authority=(Greene) R. J. Bayer |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brittonia |place=41: 397. 1989 |year=1989 }} |common_names=Canadian pussytoes;antennaire du Canada |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria canadensis |authority=Greene |rank=species |publication_title=Pittonia |publication_place=3: 275. 1898 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria canadensis var. randii |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria canadensis var. spathulata |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta var. randii |authority=(Fernald) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica subsp. canadensis |authority=(Greene) R. J. Bayer & Stebbins |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. randii |authority=(Fernald) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria spathulata |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria howellii;Antennaria howellii subsp. canadensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria howellii]]
subspecies[[Antennaria howellii subsp. canadensis]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 404 }}Plants 15–35 cm (stems stipitate-glandular). Stolons 3–8 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate to oblanceolate, 20–40 × 6–9 mm, tips mucronate, faces abaxially tomentose, adaxially green-glabrous. Cauline leaves linear, 12–30 mm, distal flagged. Heads 3–7 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate unknown; pistillate 7–10 mm. Phyllaries (sometimes rose at bases) distally white or cream. Corollas: pistillate 4–6.5 mm. Cypselae 1–1.5 mm, papillate; pappi: pistillate 7–9 mm. 2n = 56, 84 (under A. neodioica).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid spring–early summer. |habitat=Pastures, dry fields, openings in woodlands and forests, and rock barrens |elevation=0–1500 m |distribution=Man.;N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Conn.;Del.;Ind.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |discussion=

Subspecies canadensis is almost restricted to the eastern half of North America. It is probably most closely related to Antennaria racemosa of the northern Rockies and A. neglecta of the Great Plains; see R. J. Bayer 1985).

(Nfld.);N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Conn.;Del.;Ind.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |reference=None |publication title=Brittonia |publication year=1989 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_649.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria howellii |subspecies=Antennaria howellii subsp. canadensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria howellii]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria howellii subsp. howellii |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria callilepis |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria exima |authority=Greene |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria howellii;Antennaria howellii subsp. howellii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria howellii]]
subspecies[[Antennaria howellii subsp. howellii]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 405 |treatment_page=page 404 }}Plants 15–30 cm. Stolons 1–4 cm. Basal leaves 1–3-nerved, spatulate to oblanceolate, 25–40 × 9–12 mm, tips mucronate, faces abaxially tomentose, adaxially green-glabrous. Cauline leaves linear, 20–40 mm, not flagged. Heads 5–12 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate unknown; pistillate 6–7.5 mm. Phyllaries distally light brown or white. Corollas: pistillate 5–6 mm. Cypselae 1.5–2 mm, notably papillate; pappi: pistillate 6–8 mm. 2n = 56, 84, 140 (under A. neodioica).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid spring–early summer. |habitat=Pastures, dry fields, openings in deciduous woodlands and coniferous forests. and rock barrens |elevation=0–2200 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Ont.;Sask.;Yukon;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Minn.;Mont.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies howellii is most common in the western half of the range of Antennaria howellii. Based on morphology, this group of apomicts is closely related to A. racemosa of the northern Rockies (R. J. Bayer 1985) and, perhaps, to A. marginata of the southern Rockies.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria howellii subsp. neodioica |accepted_authority=(Greene) R. J. Bayer |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brittonia |place=41: 397. 1989 |year=1989 }} |common_names=Antennaire néodioïque |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria neodioica |authority=Greene |rank=species |publication_title=Pittonia |publication_place=3: 184. 1897 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria alsinoides |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria grandis |authority=(Fernald) House |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta var. attenuata |authority=(Fernald) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta var. neodioica |authority=(Greene) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. attenuata |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. chlorophylla |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. grandis |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. interjecta |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. rupicola |authority=(Fernald) Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria obovata |authority= |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria rupicola |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria howellii;Antennaria howellii subsp. neodioica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria howellii]]
subspecies[[Antennaria howellii subsp. neodioica]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 403, 404 |treatment_page=page 405 }}Plants (6–)15–35 cm. Stolons 3–8(–12) cm (leaves along stolons almost equal to those of rosettes at ends). Basal leaves 1-nerved (sometimes obscurely 3-nerved), spatulate to narrowly or broadly obovate (petiolate), 14–48 × 2.5–20 mm, tips mucronate, faces abaxially tomentose, adaxially gray-pubescent to floccose-glabrescent. Cauline leaves linear, 8–35 mm, distal flagged. Heads 4–8(–13) in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate (very uncommon) 6 mm; pistillate 6–9 mm. Phyllaries distally white or cream Corollas: staminate 3.5 mm; pistillate 3.5–6 mm. Cypselae 0.9–1.5 mm, minutely papillate; pappi: staminate 4 mm; pistillate 5.5–7 mm. 2n = 56, 84 (under A. neodioica).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid spring–early summer. |habitat=Pastures, dry fields, openings in woodlands and forests, and rock barrens and dry lake shores |elevation=0–2200 m |distribution=St. Pierre and Miquelon;Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.W.T.;N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Vt.;Va.;Wash.;W.Va.;Wis.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies neodioica is most common in the eastern half of the range of Antennaria howellii; it is also found sporadically as far west as Washington and British Columbia. Antennaria virginica is likely the primary sexual progenitor of apomicts in subsp. neodioica (R. J. Bayer 1985).

Bayer & Stebbins |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neodioica var. petaloidea |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria pedicellata |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria petaloidea |authority= |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria petaloidea var. novaboracensis |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria petaloidea var. scariosa |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria petaloidea var. subcorymbosa |authority=(Fernald) Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria stenolepis |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria howellii;Antennaria howellii subsp. petaloidea |hierarchy_nav=

tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria howellii]]
subspecies[[Antennaria howellii subsp. petaloidea]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 404 |treatment_page=page 405 }}Plants 8–35 cm. Stolons 4–9 cm (leaves along stolons smaller than in rosettes at ends). Basal leaves 1(–3)-nerved, cuneate-oblanceolate, spatulate, or spatulate-obovate (without distinct petioles), 15–45(–65) × 5–20 mm, tips mucronate, faces abaxially tomentose, adaxially gray-pubescent to floccose-glabrescent. Cauline leaves linear, 10–35 mm, mid and distal flagged. Heads 4–10(–15) in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate (uncommon) 6–6.5 mm; pistillate 7–11 mm. Phyllaries distally white or cream. Corollas: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 4–6.5(–8) mm. Cypselae 0.8–1.7 mm, minutely papillate; pappi: staminate 4–4.5 mm; pistillate 5.5–8 mm. 2n = 56, 84 (under A. neodioica).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid spring–early summer. |habitat=Pastures, dry fields, openings in woodlands and forests, and rock barrens |elevation=0–2200 m |distribution=St. Pierre and Miquelon;Alta.;B.C.;N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Ill.;Ind.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mont.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Vt.;Va.;Wash.;W.Va.;Wis.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies petaloidea is most common in the eastern half of the range of Antennaria howellii and is frequent as far west as British Columbia and Washington. Its primary sexual progenitors include A. plantaginifolia and A. neglecta (R. J. Bayer 1985).

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria lanata |accepted_authority=(Hooker) Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=3: 288. 1898 |year=1898 }} |common_names=Woolly pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria carpatica var. lanata |authority=Hooker |rank=variety |publication_title=Fl. Bor.-Amer. |publication_place=1: 329. 1834 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria lanata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria lanata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 389, 394 |treatment_page=page 399 }}Dioecious. Plants 3–20 cm (caudices branching or rhizomes stout). Stolons none. Basal leaves 3-nerved, narrowly oblanceolate, 10–60(–100) × 3–12 mm, tips acute, faces gray-woolly or tomentose. Cauline leaves linear, 5–40 mm, mid and distal flagged. Heads 3–9 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4.5–6 mm; pistillate 5–8 mm. Phyllaries (proximally light brown, dark brown, or olivaceous) distally whitish or light brown. Corollas: staminate 3–4.5 mm; pistillate 2.5–4 mm. Cypselae 1–1.6 mm, glabrous; pappi: staminate 4–5 mm; pistillate 3.5–5 mm. 2n = 28 (under A. neodioica).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Protected alpine and subalpine sites, gravelly or sandy soils near conifers at timberline |elevation=1400–3400 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Idaho;Mont.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria lanata |authority=(Hooker) Greene |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Antennaria carpatica var. lanata |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Protected alpine and subalpine sites, gravelly or sandy soils near conifers at timberline |elevation=1400–3400 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Idaho;Mont.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Pittonia |publication year=1898 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_636.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria lanata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria luzuloides |accepted_authority=Torrey & A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. N. Amer. |place=2: 430. 1843 |year=1843 }} |common_names=Rush or silvery brown pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria luzuloides |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria luzuloides]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 389, 393 |treatment_page=page 397 }}Dioecious. Plants 7–35(–70) cm (often viviparous in late season, bearing propagules in distal and, sometimes, proximal leaf axils, sometimes woody at bases). Stolons none. Basal leaves 1–3-nerved, linear to narrowly spatulate, 18–55 × 1–10 mm, tips acuminate, faces gray-tomentose. Cauline leaves narrowly oblanceolate to linear, 5–60 mm, flagged. Heads 10–110+ in racemiform to paniculiform or corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 3.5–5.5 mm; pistillate 3.5–6.5 mm. Phyllaries (relatively narrow, proximally green or golden brown, glabrous) distally white, acute. Corollas: staminate 2.5–4 mm; pistillate 2–4 mm. Cypselae 1–2 mm, sparingly papillate or papillate-strigose (hairs clavate); pappi: staminate 3–4.5 mm; pistillate 2.5–4 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

subspecies 2 (2 in the flora)

Some authors have recognized Antennaria microcephala (= A. luzuloides subsp. aberrans) as a distinct species. Given the intergradation between A. luzuloides in the strict sense and A. microcephala in the strict sense, one species with two subspecies seems justified. Perhaps the most significant difference between the subspecies is ecologic. Antennaria luzuloides is a member of the Argenteae group.

|tables= |references= }}

Bot. |place=71: 1597. 1993 |year=1993 }} |common_names=Small-headed rush pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria argentea subsp. aberrans |authority=E. E. Nelson |rank=subspecies |publication_title=Bot. Gaz. |publication_place=34: 124. 1902 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria luzuloides var. microcephala |authority=(A. Gray) Cronquist |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria microcephala |authority=A. Gray |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria pyramidata |authority=Greene |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria luzuloides;Antennaria luzuloides subsp. aberrans |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria luzuloides]]
subspecies[[Antennaria luzuloides subsp. aberrans]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 397 |treatment_page=page 398 }}Basal leaves 1(–3)-nerved, linear, 1–5 mm. Heads 10–30 in racemiform to paniculiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 3.5–4 mm; pistillate 3.5–4.5 mm. Phyllaries proximally green, distally white. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3.2 mm; pistillate 2–2.5 mm. Cypselae 1–1.5 mm, sparingly papillate-strigose; pappi: staminate 3–3.5 mm; pistillate 2.5–3 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Moist, open, meadows and drainages, lower montane, ponderosa pine zone |elevation=1000–2200 m |distribution=Calif.;Nev.;Oreg. |discussion=

Subspecies aberrans is characterized by its non-stoloniferous habit and relatively small heads in racemiform to paniculiform arrays.

Peck |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria oblanceolata |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria luzuloides;Antennaria luzuloides subsp. luzuloides |hierarchy_nav=

tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria luzuloides]]
subspecies[[Antennaria luzuloides subsp. luzuloides]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 398 }}Basal leaves (1–)3-nerved, linear to narrowly spatulate, 2–10 mm. Heads 10–110+ in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4–5.5 mm; pistillate 5–6.5 mm. Phyllaries proximally golden brown, distally white. Corollas: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 2.5–4 mm. Cypselae 1–2 mm, sparingly papillate; pappi: staminate 3–4.5 mm; pistillate 3–4 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Semidry meadows and drainages, lower montane, ponderosa pine zone |elevation=900–3200 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies luzuloides is characterized by non-stoloniferous habit and relatively small heads in corymbiform arrays.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria luzuloides subsp. luzuloides |authority= |rank=subspecies |parent rank=species |synonyms=Antennaria luzuloides var. oblanceolata;Antennaria oblanceolata |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Semidry meadows and drainages, lower montane, ponderosa pine zone |elevation=900–3200 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_631.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria luzuloides |subspecies=Antennaria luzuloides subsp. luzuloides }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria luzuloides]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria marginata |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=3: 290. 1898 |year=1898 }} |common_names=Whitemargin pussytoes |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria dioica var. marginata |authority=(Greene) Jepson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria fendleri |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria marginata var. glandulifera |authority=A. Nelson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria peramoena |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria marginata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria marginata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 392, 395, 404, 406, 409 |treatment_page=page 405 }}Dioecious or gynoecious (staminate plants in equal frequency as pistillates or none in populations, respectively). Plants 5–20 cm (stems sometimes stipitate-glandular, especially in dioecious diploids). Stolons 2–7 cm (woolly). Basal leaves 1–3-nerved, spatulate, 15–20 × 4–6 mm, tips mucronate, abaxial faces gray-tomentose, adaxial green-glabrous (margins white woolly). Cauline leaves linear, 7–16 mm, (apices acute) not flagged. Heads 5–8 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4.5–7 mm; pistillate 5–7(–9) mm. Phyllaries (relatively wide), distally white (apices acuminate). Corollas: staminate 3–5 mm; pistillate 4.5–6.5 mm. Cypselae 0.8–2 mm, glabrous or slightly papillate; pappi: staminate 3.5–5.5 mm; pistillate 5.5–8.5 mm. 2n = 28, 56, 84, 112, 140.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Moist forests, slopes and tops of ridges under Douglas fir, ponderosa pine, Engelmann spruce or Gambel oaks, openings in the forests |elevation=1500–2900 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila). |discussion=

Antennaria marginata has rims of white hairs (from the abaxial faces) around its adaxially glabrous leaves. It has both dioecious and gynoecious populations and cytotypes ranging from diploid to decaploid (R. J. Bayer and G. L. Stebbins 1987). It is probably a primary sexual progenitor of the A. parvifolia polyploid complex; the two taxa sometimes overlap morphologically; they differ in induments of basal leaves. Antennaria marginata may also be a contributor to the parentage of the A. howellii and A. rosea agamic complexes.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria marginata |authority=Greene |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Antennaria dioica var. marginata;Antennaria fendleri;Antennaria marginata var. glandulifera;Antennaria peramoena |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Moist forests, slopes and tops of ridges under Douglas fir, ponderosa pine, Engelmann spruce or Gambel oaks, openings in the forests |elevation=1500–2900 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Pittonia |publication year=1898 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_653.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria marginata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria media |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=3: 286. 1898 |year=1898 }} |common_names=Rocky Mountain pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria alpina var. media |authority=(Greene) Jepson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria austromontana |authority=E. E. Nelson |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria candida |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria densa |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria modesta |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria mucronata |authority=E. E. Nelson |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria media |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria media]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 395, 406, 415 |treatment_page=page 411 }}Dioecious or gynoecious (staminate plants rare or in equal frequency to pistillates, respectively). Plants 5–13 cm. Stolons 1–4 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate to oblanceolate, 6–19 × 2.5–6 mm, tips mucronate, faces gray-pubescent. Cauline leaves linear, 5–20 mm, not flagged (apices acute). Heads 2–5(–9) in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate (3.5–)4.5–6.5 mm; pistillate 4–8 mm. Phyllaries distally dark brown, black, or olivaceous. Corollas: staminate 2.5–4.5 mm; pistillate 3–4.5 mm. Cypselae 0.6–1.6 mm, glabrous or papillate; pappi: staminate 2.5–4.5 mm; pistillate 4–5.5 mm. 2n = 56, 98, 112.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Dry, rocky to moist alpine tundra |elevation=1500–3800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Antennaria media ranges from Arizona to Alaska; dioecious and gynoecious populations are encountered (R. J. Bayer and G. L. Stebbins 1987). The dioecious (sexual) populations are restricted primarily to California and Oregon (Bayer et al. 1990). The main distinction between A. media and A. alpina is flags on distal cauline leaves present in A. alpina and mostly absent in A. media (Bayer 1990d). Phyllaries of the pistillate plants in A. alpina tend to be acute; they are blunter in A. media. At some point, it may be preferable to follow W. L. Jepson ([1923–1925]) and some later authors and treat A. media as a subspecies of A. alpina. Antennaria media appears to be an autopolyploid derivative of A. pulchella; genes from A. pulchella may have introgressed into the A. alpina and A. parvifolia complexes indirectly through A. media.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Antennaria media |authority=Greene |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Antennaria alpina var. media;Antennaria austromontana;Antennaria candida;Antennaria densa;Antennaria modesta;Antennaria mucronata |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Dry, rocky to moist alpine tundra |elevation=1500–3800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Pittonia |publication year=1898 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_669.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria media }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria microphylla |accepted_authority=Rydberg |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Torrey Bot. Club |place=24: 303. 1897 |year=1897 }} |common_names=Littleleaf pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria bracteosa |authority=Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria microphylla var. solstitialis |authority=Lunell |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria nitida |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria rosea var. nitida |authority=(Greene) Breitung |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria solstitialis |authority=Lunell |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria microphylla |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria microphylla]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 389, 390, 396, 406, 409, 4 |treatment_page=page 407 }}Dioecious. Plants 9–30 cm (stems stipitate-glandular distally). Stolons 1–5 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate, 6–16 × 2–6 mm, tips mucronate, faces silvery gray-pubescent. Cauline leaves linear, 5–25 mm, not flagged (apices acute). Heads 6–13 in corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 5–6.5 mm; pistillate 5.5–7 mm. Phyllaries distally bright white to light yellow. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3 mm; pistillate 3–4.3 mm. Cypselae 0.7–1.2 mm, glabrous or sparingly papillate; pappi: staminate 3–4 mm; pistillate 3–5 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early–mid summer. |habitat=Moist open areas, flood plains of streams, margins of alkaline depressions, lower montane to subalpine (subarctic) |elevation=0–3200 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.W.T.;Nunavut;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Yukon;Alaska;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.Mex.;N.Dak.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Wash.;Wyo. |discussion=

Antennaria microphylla is a primary sexual progenitor of the A. rosea polyploid agamic complex (R. J. Bayer 1990b). A. Cronquist (1955) included A. rosea within his circumscription of A. microphylla. It is preferable to recognize sexual diploids as distinct from their morphologically discrete hybrid apomictic derivatives. Antennaria microphylla is always dioecious and has stems distally stipitate-glandular and white phyllaries; A. rosea is always gynoecious and has stems without glandular hairs and phyllaries only occasionally white.

Some authors (A. E. Porsild 1950; E. H. Moss 1959; Porsild and W. J. Cody 1980) have recognized A. nitida as distinct; comparisons of the nomenclatural types of the two show that they are conspecific. Antennaria microphylla has allelopathic properties (G. D. Manners and D. S. Galitz 1985).

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria monocephala |accepted_authority=de Candolle |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |place=6: 269. 1838 |year=1838 }} |common_names=Pygmy pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria alpina var. monocephala |authority=(de Candolle) Torrey & A. Gray |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria monocephala |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria monocephala]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 392, 393, 401, 412 |treatment_page=page 411 }}Dioecious or gynoecious (staminates uncommon or in equal frequencies as pistillates, respectively). Plants 5–13 cm (stems usually stipitate-glandular). Stolons 2–4 cm. Basal leaves 1-nerved, spatulate to narrowly spatulate or oblanceolate, 9–18 × 2–4 mm, tips mucronate, abaxial faces tomentose, adaxial glabrous or green-glabrescent, or both gray-pubescent. Cauline leaves linear, 4–11 mm, flagged. Heads usually borne singly (rarely 2–3). Involucres: staminate 5–7 mm; pistillate 5–8 mm. Phyllaries distally brown, dark brown, black, or olivaceous. Corollas: staminate 2.5–3.5 mm; pistillate 3.5–4 mm. Cypselae 1–1.3 mm, usually glabrous; pappi: staminate 3–4 mm (none in gynoecious populations); pistillate 4–5 mm. 2n = 28, 56, 60?, 70.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;N.W.T.;Nfld. and Labr.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont.;Wyo.;Russian Far East (Chukotka Peninsula). |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

It seems reasonable to follow in part E. Hultén’s (1968) broad concept of Antennaria monocephala (R. J. Bayer 1991). Hultén circumscribed it as containing three subspecies. The sexual phase of A. monocephala (i.e., subsp. monocephala and subsp. philonipha) is known from southern Alaska, south of the Brooks Range, and to Yukon Territory and adjacent areas of the Northwest Territories and across the Bering Strait on the Chukotka Peninsula. Within his concept of A. monocephala, Hultén also circumscribed the presumably autopolyploid apomictic form of the species as A. monocephala subsp. angustata, thereby extending the range of the species across the Canadian arctic into Greenland and down the western Cordillera into Montana and Wyoming.

Antennaria monocephala subsp. monocephala is an amphimictic progenitor of the A. alpina agamic complex, as well as the sexual progenitor of the apomicts of subsp. angustata.

|tables= |references= }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria monocephala subsp. angustata |accepted_authority=(Greene) Hultén |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Ark. Bot., n. s. |place=7: 135. 1968 |year=1968 }} |common_names=Narrow-leaved pygmy pussytoes; antennaire étroite |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Antennaria angustata |authority=Greene |rank=species |publication_title=Pittonia |publication_place=3: 284. 1898 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria alpina var. megacephala |authority=(Fernald ex Raup) S. L. Welsh |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria burwellensis |authority=Malte |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria congesta |authority=Malte |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria fernaldiana |authority=Polunin |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria hudsonica |authority=Malte |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria megacephala |authority=Fernald ex Raup |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria pygmaea |authority=Fernald |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria tansleyi |authority=Polunin |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria tweedsmuirii |authority=Polunin |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria monocephala;Antennaria monocephala subsp. angustata |hierarchy_nav=

tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria monocephala]]
subspecies[[Antennaria monocephala subsp. angustata]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 412 |treatment_page= }}Gynoecious (staminate plants unknown). Stems usually stipitate-glandular. Basal leaves spatulate to oblanceolate, faces usually gray-pubescent, adaxial sometimes green-glabrescent. 2n = 56, 60?, 70.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Moist tundra, disturbed margins of solifluction lobes, unstable, gravelly slopes |elevation=0–2900 m |distribution=Greenland;Alta.;B.C.;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);N.W.T.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont.;Wyo. |discussion=

Subspecies angustata is apomictic and has a wider geographic range than the amphimictic subsp. monocephala. It is easily recognized by heads borne singly, dark phyllaries, and gynoecious population structure.

(Labr.);N.W.T.;Nunavut;Que.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Ark. Bot., n. s. |publication year=1968 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_672.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae |genus=Antennaria |species=Antennaria monocephala |subspecies=Antennaria monocephala subsp. angustata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Antennaria monocephala]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria monocephala subsp. monocephala |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. exilis |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. monocephala var. exilis |authority=(Greene) Hultén |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. monocephala var. latisquamea |authority=Hultén |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. monocephala subsp. philonipha |authority= |rank=subspecies }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. nitens |authority=A. E. Porsild |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. philonipha |authority= |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. shumaginensis |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria monocephala;Antennaria monocephala subsp. monocephala |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria monocephala]]
subspecies[[Antennaria monocephala subsp. monocephala]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 412, 415 |treatment_page= }}Dioecious (staminates and pistillates in equal frequencies in populations). Stems stipitate-glandular. Basal leaves narrowly spatulate to oblanceolate, mostly abaxially tomentose, adaxially green-glabrous to glabrescent, sometimes both gray-pubescent. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer. |habitat=Moist tundra, often on disturbed margins of solifluction lobes or on unstable, gravelly slopes |elevation=0–1800 m |distribution=B.C.;N.W.T.;Yukon;Alaska;Russian Far East (Chukotka Peninsula). |discussion=

E. Hultén’s (1968) key distinctions between subsp. monocephala and subsp. philonipha are obscure and seemingly arbitrary (R. J. Bayer 1991). Antennaria exilis is a pubescent form of A. monocephala; complete intergradation occurs between the forms. Taxonomic recognition for the two forms does not seem warranted. Antennaria monocephala subsp. monocephala is the diploid progenitor of the apomictic clones that make up subsp. angustata, and a progenitor of the A. alpina agamic complex.

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria neglecta |accepted_authority=Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=3: 173. 1897 |year=1897 }} |common_names=Field pussytoes;antennaire négligée |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria athabascensis |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria campestris |authority=Rydberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria campestris var. athabascensis |authority=(Greene) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria chelonica |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria erosa |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria howellii var. athabascensis |authority=(Greene) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria howellii var. campestris |authority=(Rydberg) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria longifolia |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria lunellii |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria nebrascensis |authority=Greene |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta var. athabascensis |authority=(Greene) Roy L. Taylor & MacBryde |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta var. campestris |authority=(Rydberg) Steyermark |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria neglecta var. simplex |authority=Peck |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria parvula |authority= |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Antennaria wilsonii |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria neglecta |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria neglecta]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 395, 404, 405, 406 |treatment_page=page 403 }}Dioecious. Plants 4–25 cm. Stolons 2.5–18 cm. Basal leaves: 1-nerved, narrowly spatulate to cuneate-oblanceolate, 15–65 × 6–18 mm, tips mucronate, faces abaxially tomentose, adaxially gray-pubescent (green-glabrescent with age). Cauline leaves linear, 1.5–25 mm, distal flagged. Heads (1–)2–8 in corymbiform to spiciform or racemiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 4–7 mm; pistillate 6–10 mm. Phyllaries distally white. Corollas: staminate 2.7–5 mm; pistillate 4.5–6.5(–7) mm. Cypselae 0.9–1.4 mm, minutely papillate; pappi: staminate 3.5–6.5 mm; pistillate 6–8.5(–9.5) mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering early–mid spring. |habitat=Plains, grasslands, pastures, and open woodlands |elevation=0–2500 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.W.T.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ark.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mo.;Mont.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis.;Wyo. |discussion=

Antennaria neglecta is a sexual progenitor of both the A. howellii and A. parvifolia polyploid complexes and has one of the more widespread ranges among the amphimictic species in the genus in North America. Amphimicts generally have small ranges compared to those of the polyploid agamic complexes derived from them. Characteristic features of A. neglecta are its lashlike stolons that bear reduced leaves (except at the ends), flags on the distal cauline leaves, and basal leaves that are green-glabrescent with age (R. J. Bayer and G. L. Stebbins 1982).

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Antennaria parlinii |accepted_authority=Fernald |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gard. & Forest |place=10: 284. 1897 |year=1897 }} |common_names=Parlin’s pussytoes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae;Antennaria;Antennaria parlinii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Gnaphalieae]]
genus[[Antennaria]]
species[[Antennaria parlinii]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 390, 391, 394, 401 |treatment_page=page 402 }}Dioecious or gynoecious (staminate plants in equal frequencies as pistillates or none in populations, respectively). Plants 12–35(–45) cm. Stolons 3.5–11(–14) cm (mostly decumbent when young). Basal leaves 3–5-nerved, obovate-spatulate, obovate, rhombic-obovate, or suborbiculate, 30–95 × 12–45 mm, tips mucronate, faces gray-pubescent to floccose-glabrescent. Cauline leaves oblong-lanceolate, 3.5–45 mm, distalmost flagged. Heads 4–12(–15) in tight corymbiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 6–9 mm; pistillate (7–)8–13 mm. Phyllaries distally white. Corollas: staminate 3.5–5 mm; pistillate 4–7 mm. Cypselae 1–2 mm, minutely papillate; pappi: staminate 4–5 mm; pistillate 5–8 mm. 2n = 56, 84, 70, 112.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Man.;N.B.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wis. |discussion=

Subspecies 2 (2 in the flora).

The Antennaria parlinii complex consists of two fairly distinct subspecies that differ in induments of basal leaves (tomentose in subsp. fallax; glabrous in subsp. parlinii) and other characters (R. J. Bayer and G. L. Stebbins 1982). Antennaria parlinii is the most common eastern North American species (Bayer and Stebbins 1982, 1983). This complex of polyploid sexual and apomictic populations is the result of multiple hybridizations among sexual diploid species including A. plantaginifolia, A. racemosa, and A. solitaria (Bayer 1985b; Bayer and D. J. Crawford 1986). A. Cronquist (1945; H. A. Gleason and Cronquist 1991) included A. parlinii within his circumscription of A. plantaginifolia. By not including the hybrid polyploiid within the circumscription of a single one of its sexual progenitors, the circumscription here better portrays the evolutionary relationships between A. parlinii and its sexual progenitors.
