{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus pilosus |accepted_authority=Buckley |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia |place=13: 457. 1862 |year=1862 }} |common_names=Hairy lazydaisy |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus pilosus |hierarchy_nav=

tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]

species[[Aphanostephus pilosus]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page=page 352 |treatment_page=page 353 }}Annuals 6–30 cm; vestiture sparsely hispido-pilose, stem hairs spreading at right angles, straight, 0.6–2.4 mm, thick-based. Phyllary apices long-acuminate. Ray florets 13–21. Disc floret corollas: base not swollen and indurate. Cypselae: hairs apically straight; pappi coroniform, ciliate, 0.2–0.7 mm. 2n = 8.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering May–Jul. |habitat=Sand or sandy clay, open scrub oak woodlands, mesquite savannas, fields, disturbed sites, roadsides |elevation=30–200 m |distribution=Okla.;Tex. |discussion=

Aphanostephus pilosus is recognized by its reduced habit, distinct vestiture, small heads, and long-acuminate phyllary apices.

Cypselae: hairs apically straight; pappi minutely ciliate crowns 0.1–0.2 mm or absent or nearly so. 2n = 8.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;Mexico. |discussion=

Cypselae (1.1–)1.4–1.6 mm; pappi 0 or minutely ciliate rings 0.1–0.2 mm, sometimes nearly smooth. 2n = 8.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jun(–Oct). |habitat=Sand and gravel bars, limestone soils, Larrea flats, mesquite savannas, roadsides, disturbed sites |elevation=700–1600 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Nuevo León;Tamaulipas;Zacatecas). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. humilis |authority=(Bentham) B. L. Turner & Birdsong |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Aphanostephus arizonicus;Aphanostephus humilis |basionyms=Leucopsidium humile |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–Jun(–Oct). |habitat=Sand and gravel bars, limestone soils, Larrea flats, mesquite savannas, roadsides, disturbed sites |elevation=700–1600 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Nuevo León;Tamaulipas;Zacatecas). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1980 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_815.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus ramosissimus |variety=Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. humilis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphanostephus ramosissimus]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. ramosissimus |accepted_authority= |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus ramosissimus;Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. ramosissimus |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]
genus[[Aphanostephus]]
species[[Aphanostephus ramosissimus]]
variety[[Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. ramosissimus]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 353 }}Plants 20–45 cm. Involucres 3.2–4.8 mm. Ray florets 20–41. Cypselae (1–)1.2–1.4 mm; pappi coroniform, indurate, cupuliform, 0.2–0.6 mm, usually minutely ciliate. 2n = 8.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Feb–)Apr–Jul(–Sep). |habitat=Sand and sandy loam, black loam, silt, caliche, rocky limestone soils, stream bottoms, oak-juniper openings, mesquite pastures, roadsides, fencerows, disturbed sites |elevation=900–2500(–4000) m |distribution=N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Nuevo León;Tamaulipas). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. ramosissimus |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Feb–)Apr–Jul(–Sep). |habitat=Sand and sandy loam, black loam, silt, caliche, rocky limestone soils, stream bottoms, oak-juniper openings, mesquite pastures, roadsides, fencerows, disturbed sites |elevation=900–2500(–4000) m |distribution=N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Nuevo León;Tamaulipas). |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_816.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus ramosissimus |variety=Aphanostephus ramosissimus var. ramosissimus }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphanostephus ramosissimus]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus riddellii |accepted_authority=Torrey & A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. N. Amer. |place=2: 189. 1842 |year=1842 }} |common_names=Riddell’s lazydaisy |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus riddellii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]
genus[[Aphanostephus]]
species[[Aphanostephus riddellii]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page=page 351, 353 |treatment_page=page 352 }}Perennials, 10–40(–50) cm (caudices usually woody, stems 1–5+); vestiture sparsely hispidulous to puberulent, stem hairs spreading to deflexed or antrorse, 0.2–0.5 mm. Phyllary apices long-acuminate. Ray florets 30–75. Disc floret corollas: bases indurate, not conspicuously swollen. Cypselae: hairs apically glochidiate; pappi coroniform, minutely ciliate or lacerate, 0.1–0.3 mm. 2n = 10, 20.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–Aug(–Oct). |habitat=Open sites, often calcareous, often with scrubby oaks |elevation=100–500 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |discussion=

Aphanostephus riddellii is the only perennial in the genus. The caudex usually is woody, bearing numerous stems. The distal cauline leaves (upper half of stem) usually are linear, the basal and proximal cauline are conspicuously broader, spatulate, and dentate to pinnatifid. In other species, distal leaves usually are more similar to proximal.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus riddellii |authority=Torrey & A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–Aug(–Oct). |habitat=Open sites, often calcareous, often with scrubby oaks |elevation=100–500 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Coahuila). |reference=None |publication title=Fl. N. Amer. |publication year=1842 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_812.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus riddellii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphanostephus]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis |accepted_authority=(de Candolle) Trelease |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Rep. (Annual) Arkansas Geol. Surv. |place=4: 191. 1891 |year=1891 }} |common_names=Arkansas lazydaisy |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Keerlia skirrhobasis |authority=de Candolle |rank=species |publication_title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |publication_place=5: 310. 1836 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]
genus[[Aphanostephus]]
species[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page=page 351 |treatment_page=page 352 }}Annuals, 5–45 cm; vestiture hirsuto-pilose and/or puberulent, stem hairs spreading to deflexed, 0.1–0.3 mm. Phyllary apices acute to short-acuminate. Ray florets (10–)25–45. Disc floret corollas: bases (mature) bulbous-swollen, indurate. Cypselae: hairs apically 1-directionally coiled; pappi usually coroniform, uneven, rarely of acute to awn-tipped scales 0.2–2 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ark.;Fla.;Kans.;La.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;n Mexico. |discussion=

Varieties 3 (3 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaves thickened, densely, almost felty gray-hairy; sand dunes along Gulf Coast |[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius|Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Leaves not strongly thickened or felty gray-hairy; sandy soils, interior localities |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Pappi of acute or awn-tipped scales or setiform scales 0.4–2 mm |[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi|Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Pappi coroniform, uneven, ciliate, 0.1–0.3 mm, rarely of awn-tipped scales |[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis|Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis |authority=(de Candolle) Trelease |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Keerlia skirrhobasis |family=Asteraceae |distribution=Ark.;Fla.;Kans.;La.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex.;n Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Rep. (Annual) Arkansas Geol. Surv. |publication year=1891 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_808.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Aphanostephus]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi |accepted_authority=(S. F. Blake) B. L. Turner |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=56: 94. 1984 |year=1984 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Aphanostephus kidderi |authority=S. F. Blake |rank=species |publication_title=Contr. Gray Herb. |publication_place=53: 23. 1918 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]
genus[[Aphanostephus]]
species[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]
variety[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 352 }}Plants (10–)15–35 cm. Stems erect to decumbent, hirsuto-pilose and/or puberulent, hairs (0.2–)0.5–1.2 mm. Leaves not strongly thickened or felty gray-hairy. Ray florets 1–9–40. Pappi of acute or awn-tipped or setiform scales 0.4–2 mm. 2n = 6.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–Jun(–Aug). |habitat=Sandy or gravelly soils, often in matorral and scrublands |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Tamaulipas). |discussion=

Apparent intergrades between var. kidderi and var. skirrhobasis are relatively common. There is a greater tendency in Aphanostephus skirrhobasis for leaves to be lobed or pinnatifid over the whole stem than in the other species.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi |authority=(S. F. Blake) B. L. Turner |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms=Aphanostephus kidderi |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–Jun(–Aug). |habitat=Sandy or gravelly soils, often in matorral and scrublands |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico (Tamaulipas). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1984 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_809.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis |variety=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. kidderi }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]
genus[[Aphanostephus]]
species[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]
variety[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 352 }}Plants 10–30(–50) cm. Stems erect to decumbent, puberulent, hairs spreading-deflexed, 0.1–0.3 mm. Leaves not strongly thickened or felty gray-hairy. Ray florets (18–)24–45. Pappi coroniform, usually uneven, ciliate, 0.1–0.3 mm, rarely of awn-tipped scales. 2n = 6.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Mar–)Apr–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Sand, sandy loam, sandy clay, silt, gravel, river terraces, oak woodlands, mesquite savannas, fields, roadsides |elevation=10–900 m |distribution=Ark.;Kans.;La.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Mar–)Apr–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Sand, sandy loam, sandy clay, silt, gravel, river terraces, oak woodlands, mesquite savannas, fields, roadsides |elevation=10–900 m |distribution=Ark.;Kans.;La.;N.Mex.;Okla.;Tex. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_810.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis |variety=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. skirrhobasis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius |accepted_authority=Shinners |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Wrightia |place=1: 106. 1946 |year=1946 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Astereae;Aphanostephus;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis;Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Astereae]]
genus[[Aphanostephus]]
species[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]
variety[[Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius]]
|volume=Volume 20 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 352 }}Plants 5–40 cm. Stems erect to decumbent, densely puberulent-hispidulous, hairs spreading to deflexed, 0.1–0.5 mm. Leaves thickened, densely, almost felty gray-hairy. Ray florets (10–)22–44. Pappi coroniform, uneven, often of awn-tipped or ciliate scales, 0.1–0.3 mm. 2n = 6.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Feb–)Apr–Dec. |habitat=Sand dunes near beaches, coastal sands, Rio Grande plains |elevation=0–30 m |distribution=Fla.;La.;Tex.;Mexico (Tamaulipas). |discussion=

Variety thalassius is found on the Gulf coast; it differs from var. skirrhobasis primarily in vestiture.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius |authority=Shinners |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Feb–)Apr–Dec. |habitat=Sand dunes near beaches, coastal sands, Rio Grande plains |elevation=0–30 m |distribution=Fla.;La.;Tex.;Mexico (Tamaulipas). |reference=None |publication title=Wrightia |publication year=1946 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V20_811.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Astereae |genus=Aphanostephus |species=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis |variety=Aphanostephus skirrhobasis var. thalassius }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphanostephus skirrhobasis]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphragmus |accepted_authority=Andrzejowski ex de Candolle |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |place=1: 209. 1824 |year=1824 }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Oreas |authority=Chamisso & Schlechtendal |rank=genus }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Orobium |authority=Reichenbach |rank=genus }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Staintoniella |authority=H. Hara |rank=genus }} |hierarchy=Brassicaceae;Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae;Aphragmus |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Brassicaceae]]
tribe[[Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae]]
genus[[Aphragmus]]
|etymology=Greek a-, not or without, and phragma, septum, alluding to its lack in fruit of some species |volume=Volume 7 |mention_page=page 231, 232, 239, 245 |treatment_page=page 256 }}Plants not scapose; (sometimes rhizomatous, caudex thick, covered with persistent petiolar remains); glabrous or pubescent, trichomes simple or forked, (less than 0.1 mm). Stems erect or ascending, branched basally. Leaves basal and cauline; petiolate or sessile; basal rosulate, petiolate, blade margins entire; cauline petiolate or sessile, blade margins entire. Racemes (few- to several-flowered), bracteate throughout or basally. Fruiting pedicels [erect] ascending, divaricate, sometimes recurved, slender. Flowers: sepals (sometimes persistent), oblong; petals broadly obovate or spatulate, claw subequaling sepal, (apex rounded [obtuse]); stamens slightly tetradynamous; filaments dilated or not basally; anthers obtuse; nectar glands confluent, subtending bases of stamens. Fruits silicles or siliques, sessile or subsessile, oblong, elliptic, or lanceolate [ovate, linear]; valves each with obscure or distinct midvein, (smooth), glabrous; replum flattened basally; septum absent [complete and membranous]; style obsolete or distinct (to 2 mm); stigma capitate. Seeds plump, not winged, oblong or ovoid (on filiform funicles often longer than seeds); seed coat (minutely reticulate), not mucilaginous when wetted; cotyledons incumbent. x = 7.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=nw North America;Asia (Himalaya;Russian Far East). |discussion=

Species 11 (1 in the flora).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=al-shehbaz2003a |text=Al-Shehbaz, I. A. 2003. Aphragmus bouffordii, a new species from Tibet and a synopsis of Aphragmus (Brassicaceae). Harvard Pap. Bot. 8: 25–27. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=ebel1998a |text=Ebel, A. L. 1998. Notes on genus Aphragmus Andrz. (Brassicaceae). Turczaninowia 1(4): 20–27. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphragmus |author=Ihsan A. Al-Shehbaz |authority=Andrzejowski ex de Candolle |rank=genus |parent rank=tribe |synonyms=Oreas;Orobium;Staintoniella |basionyms= |family=Brassicaceae |distribution=nw North America;Asia (Himalaya;Russian Far East). |reference=al-shehbaz2003a;ebel1998a |publication title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |publication year=1824 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V7/V7_335.xml |tribe=Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae |genus=Aphragmus }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aphragmus eschscholtzianus |accepted_authority=Andrzejowski ex de Candolle |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |place=1: 210. 1824 |year=1824 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eutrema eschscholtzianum |authority=(Andrzejowski ex de Candolle) B. L. Robinson |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Brassicaceae;Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae;Aphragmus;Aphragmus eschscholtzianus |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Brassicaceae]]
tribe[[Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae]]
genus[[Aphragmus]]
species[[Aphragmus eschscholtzianus]]
|volume=Volume 7 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 256 }}Stems 2–6 cm; glabrous or sparsely puberulent, trichomes simple. Basal leaves: petiole 0.5–3 cm (base persistent, papery, broadly expanded, narrowly triangular, 0.2–0.4 cm wide); blade (subfleshy), spatulate, oblanceolate, or ovate, 0.5–1.2 cm × 2–4 mm, base cuneate to attenuate, apex obtuse, surfaces glabrous or puberulent. Cauline leaves (bracts), sessile; blade similar to basal, narrower, smaller distally. Racemes subumbellate. Fruiting pedicels 1.5–5 mm, glabrous or sparsely puberulent adaxially. Flowers: sepals often purplish, 1.5–2 × 0.7–1 mm, glabrous; petals purple with darker veins, 2–3 × 1–2 mm; filaments 1.5–2 mm; anthers 0.2–0.4 mm; gynophore 0–0.7 mm. Fruits compressed, 5–15 × 2–3 mm; style 0.2–1 mm. Seeds light brown, 1.2–1.7 × 0.8–1 mm; funicles 2–3 mm. 2n = 14.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul. |habitat=Limestone slopes, subalpine valleys, wet cliffs, ridges, fine gravel saturated by snowmelt |elevation=0-2100 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Asia (Russian Far East [Chukchi Peninsula]). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aphragmus eschscholtzianus |authority=Andrzejowski ex de Candolle |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Eutrema eschscholtzianum |basionyms= |family=Brassicaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul. |habitat=Limestone slopes, subalpine valleys, wet cliffs, ridges, fine gravel saturated by snowmelt |elevation=0-2100 m |distribution=Yukon;Alaska;Asia (Russian Far East [Chukchi Peninsula]). |reference=None |publication title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |publication year=1824 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V7/V7_336.xml |tribe=Brassicaceae tribe Aphragmeae |genus=Aphragmus |species=Aphragmus eschscholtzianus }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aphragmus]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aplectrum |accepted_authority=(Nuttall) Torrey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |place=2: 197. 1818 |year=1818 }} |common_names=Putty-root;Adam-and-Eve;aplectrum d’hiver |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orchidaceae;Orchidaceae subfam. Epidendroideae;Orchidaceae tribe Cymbidieae;Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae;Aplectrum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orchidaceae]]
subfamily[[Orchidaceae subfam. Epidendroideae]]
tribe[[Orchidaceae tribe Cymbidieae]]
subtribe[[Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae]]
genus[[Aplectrum]]
|etymology=Greek a, without, and plectron, spur |volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 495, 497 |treatment_page=page 632 }}Herbs, perennial. Roots in fascicles at base of pseudobulb, slender, fibrous. Corms connected by slender rhizomes. Stems scapes, cormose. Leaves produced in late summer–fall, withering in spring, solitary, borne at distal end of corm, plicate. Inflorescences solitary, lax racemes from lateral nodes on corm; floral bracts inconspicuous; cauline bracts sheathing, large. Flowers several, resupinate; sepals to 15 mm; lip 3-lobed, with 3 parallel lamellae; column compressed; pollinarium 1; pollinea 4, attached to viscidium by short stipe; stigma deeply concave. Fruits capsules, pendent, straight, 7 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=e North America;e Asia (Japan). |discussion=

Species 2 (1 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aplectrum |author=Charles J. Sheviak;Paul M. Catling |authority=(Nuttall) Torrey |rank=genus |parent rank=subtribe |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Orchidaceae |distribution=e North America;e Asia (Japan). |reference=None |publication title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |publication year=1818 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_1295.xml |subfamily=Orchidaceae subfam. Epidendroideae |tribe=Orchidaceae tribe Cymbidieae |subtribe=Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae |genus=Aplectrum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aplectrum hyemale |accepted_authority=(Muhlenburg ex Willdenow) Torrey |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |place=2: 198. 1818 |year=1818 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Cymbidium hyemale |authority=Muhlenburg ex Willdenow |rank=species |publication_title=Sp. Pl. |publication_place=4(1): 107. 1805 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Orchidaceae;Orchidaceae subfam. Epidendroideae;Orchidaceae tribe Cymbidieae;Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae;Aplectrum;Aplectrum hyemale |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Orchidaceae]]
subfamily[[Orchidaceae subfam. Epidendroideae]]
tribe[[Orchidaceae tribe Cymbidieae]]
subtribe[[Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae]]
genus[[Aplectrum]]
species[[Aplectrum hyemale]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 628 |treatment_page=page 632 }}Plants 18–50 cm. Leaves persistent, petiolate; blade narrowly to broadly elliptic, prominently and irregularly plicate, 10–20 × 3–8 cm, abaxially usually maroon or greenish purple, adaxially dark green with whitish veins. Inflorescences: floral bracts inconspicuous, 3–7 × 1.5 mm, apex subulate to acuminate. Flowers prominent but inconspicuously colored; sepals spreading, greenish or yellowish suffused with magenta or purple-brown, oblong-oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic, 10–15 × 1.8–4 mm; petals parallel to column, greenish or yellowish, suffused with magenta or purple-brown, oblong-oblanceolate, 9–13 × 1.8–3.5 mm; lip white with magenta spots, obovate in outline, 9–12 × 7–9 mm, apex 3-lobed, lateral lobes ascending and flanking column, middle lobe broadly expanded, crenate; column 7 × 2 mm. Capsules ellipsoid, strongly ribbed, 15–30 × 7–12 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring. |habitat=Moist, deciduous, upland to swampy forests |elevation=0–1200 m |distribution=Ont.;Que.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mo.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;Tenn.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aplectrum hyemale |authority=(Muhlenburg ex Willdenow) Torrey |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Cymbidium hyemale |family=Orchidaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring. |habitat=Moist, deciduous, upland to swampy forests |elevation=0–1200 m |distribution=Ont.;Que.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mo.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;Tenn.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |reference=None |publication title=Gen. N. Amer. Pl. |publication year=1818 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_1296.xml |subfamily=Orchidaceae subfam. Epidendroideae |tribe=Orchidaceae tribe Cymbidieae |subtribe=Orchidaceae (tribe Cymbidieae) subtribe Corallorhizinae |genus=Aplectrum |species=Aplectrum hyemale }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aplectrum]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aplodon |accepted_authority=R. Brown |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Chlor. Melvill., |place=41. 1823 |year=1823 }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Haplodon |authority=R. Brown ex I. Hagen |rank=genus }} |hierarchy=Splachnaceae;Aplodon |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Splachnaceae]]
genus[[Aplodon]]
|etymology=Greek haplo- , single, and odon, tooth, alluding to single layer of peristome teeth |volume=Volume 28 |mention_page=page 15, 650 |treatment_page=page 28 }}Plants in slender lax tufts, light green distally. Stems 6 cm; rhizoids dense proximally. Stem leaves broadly ovate or obovate; margins entire; apex obtuse to acute and abruptly short-acuminate; costa ending before apex; proximal laminal cells rounded-rectangular; distal cells oblong-hexagonal. Sexual condition autoicous. Seta 1–2 cm, twisted, flexuose. Capsule not cleistocarpous, reddish, black with age, shrunken and widest at mouth when dry, ovate when moist; hypophysis same color as urn, rounded, elongate, not or slightly wider than urn; annulus weakly differentiated; operculum hemispheric, sometimes apiculate; peristome single; exostome teeth 8–12, at first in pairs, then separate, erect or reflexed, rudimentary. Calyptra mitrate or cucullate, conic, not constricted beyond base. Spores 10–15 µm, smooth.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=n North America;n Eurasia;subarctic to Arctic regions. |discussion=

Species 1.

Although plants of Aplodon have an inflated hypophysis, based upon the molecular data, placement of the genus is not well resolved within Splachnaceae, and its relationship to or within this family requires further study (B. Goffinet et. al. 2004).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=brassard1978a |text=Brassard, G. R. 1978. An extensive subfossil deposit of the Arctic moss Aplodon wormskioldii. Canad. J. Bot. 56: 1852–1859. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=steere1973a |text=Steere, W. C. 1973. Observations on the genus Aplodon (Musci: Splachnaceae). Bryologist. 76: 347–355. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Aplodon |authority=R. Brown |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms=Haplodon |basionyms= |family=Splachnaceae |distribution=n North America;n Eurasia;subarctic to Arctic regions. |reference=brassard1978a;steere1973a |publication title=Chlor. Melvill., |publication year=1823 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V28/V28_25.xml |genus=Aplodon }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Splachnaceae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aplodon wormskioldii |accepted_authority=(Hornemann) R. Brown |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Chlor. Melvill., |place=41. 1823 |year=1823 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Splachnum wormskioldii |authority=Hornemann |rank=species |publication_title=in G. C. Oeder, Fl. Dan. |publication_place=10(28): 8, plate 1659. 1819 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Tayloria wormskioldii |authority=(Hornemann) Lindberg |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Tetraplodon wormskioldii |authority=(Hornemann) Lindberg |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Splachnaceae;Aplodon;Aplodon wormskioldii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Splachnaceae]]
genus[[Aplodon]]
species[[Aplodon wormskioldii]]
|volume=Volume 28 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 29 }}Stems with branches often flagellate. Leaves shrunken when dry, erectopatent when moist, concave, 1–1.5 × 2–3 mm; costa sometimes 2-fid. Perichaetia terminal on axillary branches. Seta hyaline, very slender. Capsule 1.5–2 × 0.5–1 mm including hypophysis; columella included; exostome teeth of 2 layers of cells, short, truncate. Spores yellow-green.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Capsules mature summer. |habitat=Dung, animal remains |elevation=low to moderate elevations |distribution=Greenland;Man.;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);N.W.T.;Nunavut;Que.;Alaska;n Eurasia. |discussion=

Aplodon wormskioldii can be distinguished by the hyaline, slender and twisted seta. The gametophyte differs from other species of Splachnaceae in having shorter and much wider apical cells and a wider marginal row of laminal cells.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aplodon wormskioldii |authority=(Hornemann) R. Brown |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Tayloria wormskioldii;Tetraplodon wormskioldii |basionyms=Splachnum wormskioldii |family=Splachnaceae |phenology=Capsules mature summer. |habitat=Dung, animal remains |elevation=low to moderate elevations |distribution=Greenland;Man.;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);N.W.T.;Nunavut;Que.;Alaska;n Eurasia. |reference=None |publication title=Chlor. Melvill., |publication year=1823 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V28/V28_26.xml |genus=Aplodon |species=Aplodon wormskioldii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aplodon]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apluda |accepted_authority=L. |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Poaceae;Poaceae subfam. Panicoideae;Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae;Apluda |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Poaceae]]
subfamily[[Poaceae subfam. Panicoideae]]
tribe[[Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae]]
genus[[Apluda]]
|volume=Volume 25 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 649 }}Plants perennial; often scrambling. Culms to 3 m, decumbent. Leaves not aromatic; sheaths open; ligules membranous; blades linear, often pseudopetiolate. Inflorescences false panicles, individual inflorescence units with solitary rames; rames to 1 cm, often enclosed by the subtending leaf sheath, with 1 sessile and 2 unequally pedicellate spikelets; disarticulation at the base of the sessile spikelets, sometimes also at the base of the pedicellate spikelets. Sessile spikelets laterally compressed, with a large, bulbous callus; lower glumes coriaceous, without keels or wings, smooth, bidentate; upper glumes unawned; upper lemmas awned or unawned. Pedicels flat, wide, adjacent to each other, appressed but not fused to the rame axes. Pedicellate spikelets usually unequal, unawned, 1 staminate or bisexual and as large as the sessile spikelet, the other sterile and usually smaller, x = 10.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Md. |discussion=

Apluda is treated here as consisting of a single weedy species that is native to tropical Asia and Australia, where it grows primarily in thickets and forest margins. It is not known to be established in the Flora region.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=clayton1994b |text=Clayton, W.D. 1994. Apluda. Pp. 35-37 in W.D. Clayton, G. Davidse, F. Gould, M. Lazarides, and T.R. Soderstrom. A Revised Handbook to the Flora of Ceylon, vol. 8 (ed. M.D. Dassanayake). Amerind Publishing Co., New Delhi, India. 458 pp. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=reed1964a |text=Reed, C.F. 1964. A flora of the chrome and manganese ore piles at Canton, in the Port of Baltimore, Maryland and at Newport News, Virginia, with descriptions of genera and species new to the flora of the eastern United States. Phytologia 10:321-405. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Apluda |author=Mary E. Barkworth; |authority=L. |rank=genus |parent rank=tribe |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Poaceae |distribution=Md. |reference=clayton1994b;reed1964a |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/200273ad09963decb8fc72550212de541d86569d/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V25/V25_1569.xml |subfamily=Poaceae subfam. Panicoideae |tribe=Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae |genus=Apluda }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apluda mutica |accepted_authority=L. |publications= |common_names=Mauritian grass |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Poaceae;Poaceae subfam. Panicoideae;Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae;Apluda;Apluda mutica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Poaceae]]
subfamily[[Poaceae subfam. Panicoideae]]
tribe[[Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae]]
genus[[Apluda]]
species[[Apluda mutica]]
|volume=Volume 25 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 649 }}Culms to 3 m, decumbent and rooting from the lower nodes. Blades 5-25 cm long, 2-10 mm wide, flat, attenuate distally. Inflorescences 3-40 cm; rames to 10 mm long, subtending sheaths 3.5-10 mm, narrowly ovate in side view. Sessile spikelets 2-6 mm; lower glumes narrowly elliptic-lanceolate; upper lemmas unawned or awned; awns 4-12 mm. Pedicellate spikelets broadly lanceolate; larger spikelets 2-5 mm; smaller spikelets 2-4 mm. 2n = 20, 40.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Md. |discussion=

Reed (1964) reported finding Apluda mutica on chrome ore piles in Canton, Maryland (a temporary unloading ground for ores). The report has not been verified because his voucher specimens were not accessible at the time of writing. They were acquired by the Missouri Botanical Garden in 2001.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Apluda mutica |authority=L. |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Poaceae |illustrator=Linda A. Vorobik;Hana Pazdírková |illustration copyright=Utah State University |distribution=Md. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/200273ad09963decb8fc72550212de541d86569d/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V25/V25_1570.xml |subfamily=Poaceae subfam. Panicoideae |tribe=Poaceae tribe Andropogoneae |genus=Apluda |species=Apluda mutica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Apluda]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apodanthaceae |accepted_authority=Van Tieghem ex Takhtajan |publications= |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Apodanthaceae |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Apodanthaceae]]
|volume=Volume 6 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 183 }}Plants apparently dioecious stem parasites, achlorophyllous; roots not produced. Stems not sessile, 1-locular anthers connate to distal portion of central column, not produced in pistillate flowers, column expanded at apex, sometimes into knob or disc; pistils in staminate flowers with only stylar column present, in pistillate flowers ovary partially inferior, indistinctly 4- or 5-carpellate, 1-locular; placentation parietal; ovules numerous. Fruits berrylike capsules, ± fleshy. Seeds numerous, minute.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=sw United States;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America;sw Asia;Africa;Australia;mostly in tropical areas. |discussion=

Genera 2, species 10 or 11 (1 species in the flora).

The genera of Apodanthaceae as here circumscribed previously have been included in Rafflesiaceae. Molecular studies have provided evidence that the Rafflesiaceae as traditionally circumscribed (A. Cronquist 1981; W. Meijer 1993) are polyphyletic and includes three or four independent lineages (T. J. Barkman et al. 2004; D. L. Nickrent et al., www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2148-4-40; C. C. Davis et al. 2007). The Indo-Malaysian genera Rafflesia R. Brown, Rhizanthes Dumortier, and Sapria Griffith (Rafflesiaceae in the narrow sense, 20–25 species, stem and root parasites of Vitaceae), which are characterized by very large flowers, currently are thought to be related to Euphorbiaceae (Malpighiales). The two (or more) species of Mitrastemon Makino (Mitrastemonaceae, root parasites of Fagaceae), with a disjunct distribution in the Neotropics and eastern and southeastern Asia, are now placed with the Ericales. The two genera of Cytinaceae, the neotropical Bdallophytum Eichler (two species, root parasites of Burseraceae) and Cytinus Linnaeus (about eight species, root parasites on various taxa), appear to be related to the Malvales. A. Blarer et al. (2004) thought that the affinities of the Apodanthaceae were either with the Malvales or Cucurbitales; more recent molecular analyses have provided some support for the latter placement (N. Filipowicz and S. S. Renner 2010; H. Schaefer and Renner 2011b).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=bellot2014a |text=Bellot, S. and S. S. Renner. 2014. The systematics of the worldwide endoparasite family Apodanthaceae (Cucurbitales), with a key, a map, and color photos of most species. PhytoKeys 36: 41–57. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=filipowicz2010a |text=Filipowicz, N., and S. S. Renner. 2010. The worldwide holoparasitic Apodanthaceae confidently placed in the Cucurbitales by nuclear and mitochondrial gene trees. B. M. C. Evol. Biol. 10: 219. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Apodanthaceae |author=George Yatskievych |authority=Van Tieghem ex Takhtajan |rank=family |parent rank= |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Apodanthaceae |illustrator=John Myers |illustration copyright=Flora of North America Association |distribution=sw United States;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America;sw Asia;Africa;Australia;mostly in tropical areas. |reference=bellot2014a;filipowicz2010a |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V6/V6_804.xml }}[[Category:Treatment]]
{{#ask: [[Plate of taxon::<q>[[Category:Apodanthaceae]]</q>]] | ?Plate of taxon.Taxon family=Family | ?Plate of taxon=Taxon | ?Plate of taxon.Illustrator | format=gallery | limit=3 }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apodanthera |accepted_authority=Arnott |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=J. Bot. (Hooker) |place=3: 274. 1841 |year=1841 }} |common_names=Melon loco |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Cucurbitaceae;Apodanthera |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Cucurbitaceae]]
genus[[Apodanthera]]
|etymology=Greek a- , without, podos, foot, and anthera, anther, alluding to sessile anthers |volume=Volume 6 |mention_page=page 5 |treatment_page=page 28 }}Plants perennial, monoecious [dioecious], prostrate and trailing; stems annual, strigose; roots tuberous; tendrils unbranched or 2–3-branched. Leaves: blade reniform to orbiculate-cordate, unlobed or shallowly palmately 5-lobed [3–5-foliolate], lobes rounded, margins dentate, often undulate-crisped, surfaces eglandular. Inflorescences: staminate flowers (1–)2–5 in racemes [corymbs] from proximal axils; pistillate flowers 5–12 in fascicles in distal axils [solitary]; bracts filiform-subulate or absent. Flowers: hypanthium subcylindric to narrowly funnelform; sepals 5, linear-lanceolate; petals 5, distinct, yellow, oblong-obovate to elliptic-oblanceolate, [ovate or ovate-lanceolate], [1–]16–25(–35) mm, glabrate, corolla broadly funnelform-campanulate to rotate. Staminate flowers: stamens 3; filaments inserted near hypanthium rim, distinct, nearly vestigial; thecae distinct, oblong to suborbiculate, connective narrow; pistillodes absent. Pistillate flowers: ovary 3-locular, ovoid to oblong; ovules ca. 3–35 per locule; style 1, short-columnar to nearly absent; stigmas 3, linear; staminodes absent. Fruits pepos, silvery green to green with darker, raised, broad, longitudinal stripes, subglobose to depressed-globose [ovoid or ellipsoid], smooth or ribbed, indehiscent. Seeds [8–]30–80[–100], ellipsoid-obovoid [ovoid to obovoid or broadly ellipsoid], biconvex [compressed], not arillate, margins a broad, flat, light-colored band, surface smooth. x = 14.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=sw United States;Mexico;Central America;South America. |discussion=

Species ca. 19 (1 in the flora).

Plants of Apodanthera were reported to be gender-diphasic, switching from staminate to pistillate (V. A. Delesalle 1989). Apodanthera herrerae Harms, a species of Andean South America, is grown for its edible tubers.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Apodanthera |authority=Arnott |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Cucurbitaceae |distribution=sw United States;Mexico;Central America;South America. |reference=None |publication title=J. Bot. (Hooker) |publication year=1841 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V6/V6_43.xml |genus=Apodanthera }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Cucurbitaceae]]

revision.comment: Bot: Adding category [[:Category:Revised Since Print|Revised Since Print]]
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apodanthera undulata |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Smithsonian Contr. Knowl. |place=5(6): 60. 1853 |year=1853 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Cucurbitaceae;Apodanthera;Apodanthera undulata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Cucurbitaceae]]
genus[[Apodanthera]]
species[[Apodanthera undulata]]
|volume=Volume 6 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 29 }}{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico. |discussion=

Varieties 2 (1 in the flora).

Apodanthera undulata in the flora area is recognized by its reniform, undulate-margined, and white-backed leaves and yellow petals. Variety australis McVaugh (A. aspera Cogniaux) differs in reduced vestiture and pistillate inflorescence; it occurs in Mexico (Aguascalientes, Guanajuato, Hidalgo, Jalisco, Michoacán, Nayarit, Oaxaca, Querétaro, San Luis Potosí, Zacatecas). According to McVaugh, the two varieties are allopatric.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Apodanthera undulata |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Cucurbitaceae |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Smithsonian Contr. Knowl. |publication year=1853 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V6/V6_44.xml |genus=Apodanthera |species=Apodanthera undulata }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Apodanthera]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apodanthera undulata var. undulata |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Cucurbitaceae;Apodanthera;Apodanthera undulata;Apodanthera undulata var. undulata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Cucurbitaceae]]
genus[[Apodanthera]]
species[[Apodanthera undulata]]
variety[[Apodanthera undulata var. undulata]]
|volume=Volume 6 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 29 }}Vines fetid; branches to 3 m, harshly strigose; tendrils usually branched from 1–5 cm beyond base. Leaves: petiole 3–7 cm; blade 8–15 cm wide, surfaces moderately to densely white-sericeous abaxially, glabrous adaxially. Inflorescences: staminate flowers in long-pedunculate racemes; pistillate flowers in loose fascicles; peduncle erect, 1–2 cm in flower, 6–9 cm in fruit. Flowers: hypanthium 10–18 mm; sepals erect, not recurving. Pepos 6–10 cm. Seeds light brown, 9–12 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering May–Sep. |habitat=Roadsides, gravelly stream terraces, interfan alluvium, dunes, flats, rocky slopes, lava beds, grasslands, creosote scrub, Chihuahuan desert scrub of Flourensia-Larrea, mesquite, oak chaparral, oak-juniper woodlands |elevation=800–1700 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Sonora). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Apodanthera undulata var. undulata |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Cucurbitaceae |phenology=Flowering May–Sep. |habitat=Roadsides, gravelly stream terraces, interfan alluvium, dunes, flats, rocky slopes, lava beds, grasslands, creosote scrub, Chihuahuan desert scrub of Flourensia-Larrea, mesquite, oak chaparral, oak-juniper woodlands |elevation=800–1700 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Sonora). |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V6/V6_45.xml |genus=Apodanthera |species=Apodanthera undulata |variety=Apodanthera undulata var. undulata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Apodanthera undulata]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aponogeton |accepted_authority=Linnaeus f. |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Supplementum Plantarum |place=32.; 214. 1782 |year=1782 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Aponogetonaceae;Aponogeton |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Aponogetonaceae]]
genus[[Aponogeton]]
|etymology=Greek, from aquatic habitat |volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs with milky sap. Leaves sheathing at base; axillary scales present. Inflorescences branched [unbranched], projected above water. Flowers bilaterally symmetric, sessile; stamens 6–18–[50]; filaments distinct; anthers 2-locular; pistils 2–6[–9], sessile. Fruits: beak terminal [lateral], curved or straight. Seeds: endosperm absent; seed coat single or double. x = 8.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America;native;Africa;tropical regions;Eastern Hemisphere. |discussion=

Species 47 (1 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aponogeton |authority=Linnaeus f. |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Aponogetonaceae |distribution=North America;native;Africa;tropical regions;Eastern Hemisphere. |reference=None |publication title=Supplementum Plantarum |publication year=1782 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_184.xml |genus=Aponogeton }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aponogetonaceae]]

revision.comment: Corrected authority to match printed version
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aponogeton distachyos |accepted_authority=Linnaeus f. |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Supplementum Plantarum |place=32, 214. 1782 (as distachyon) }} |common_names=Cape-pondweed;water-hawthorne |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aponogeton distachyos var. lagrangei |authority=André |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Aponogetonaceae;Aponogeton;Aponogeton distachyos |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Aponogetonaceae]]
genus[[Aponogeton]]
species[[Aponogeton distachyos]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Leaves floating; petiole to 100 cm; blade ovate, narrowly oval, or narrowly lanceolate, 6–23 × 1.5–7.5 cm, base rounded to attenuate, apex obtuse to acute; veins 7–9. Inflorescences: spikes 1 or more, to 4.5 cm; spathe ca. 3 cm. Flowers in 2 rows, secund; tepals becoming green, enlarging, 10–15 × 3.5–6 mm, to 30 mm in fruit; veins 13 or more; stamens 3–4.5 mm; filaments expanded basally; anthers blackish purple; pollen yellow; pistils 2.5–3 × 0.7–1 mm; ovules usually 4. Fruits to 22 × 6 mm; beak 5 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late winter–spring (Mar–Apr), fall (Oct–Nov). |habitat=Quiet ponds |elevation=0–550 m |distribution=Calif.;South America;Europe;Africa;Australia. |introduced=true |discussion=

Aponogeton distachyos is native to temperate South Africa and has become widely established in Australia. It is very popular in water gardening because it blooms during the cooler periods of the year. The plant does not do well in the heat of the summer. It flowers early in the growing season, goes dormant during the summer, and flowers again late in the season. Where the weather is mild, it will flower all winter. Presently, it is known in North America only from central-coastal and southern California.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aponogeton distachyos |authority=Linnaeus f. |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Aponogeton distachyos var. lagrangei |basionyms= |family=Aponogetonaceae |phenology=Flowering late winter–spring (Mar–Apr), fall (Oct–Nov). |habitat=Quiet ponds |elevation=0–550 m |distribution=Calif.;South America;Europe;Africa;Australia. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Supplementum Plantarum |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_427.xml |genus=Aponogeton |species=Aponogeton distachyos }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aponogeton]]

revision.comment: Corrected species number in family to match printed version
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aponogetonaceae |accepted_authority=J. Agardh |publications= |common_names=Aponogeton or Cape-pondweed Family |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Aponogetonaceae |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Aponogetonaceae]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 39 }}Herbs, perennial, rhizomatous, caulescent; turions absent. Leaves alternate, floating [submersed], petiolate [sessile]; sheath not persisting longer than blade, not leaving circular scar when shed, not ligulate, not auriculate; blade ovate to narrowly lanceolate [linear]; intravaginal squamules (i.e., minute appressed, planate trichomes attached at basal edge) scales, more than 2. Inflorescences terminal, spikes, subtended by spathe, pedunculate; peduncle following fertilization not elongating, not spiraling. Flowers bisexual [unisexual]; subtending bracts absent; perianth present [absent]; tepals 1[–6]; stamens 6–18[–50] in 2–3[–4] series, not epitepalous; anthers distinct, dehiscing longitudinally; pollen ellipsoid; pistils 2–6[–9], distinct, not stipitate; ovules basal-marginal, anatropous. Fruits follicles. Seeds 4; embryo straight.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America;s Africa;and tropical regions of Eastern Hemisphere. |discussion=

Genus 1, species 52 (1 species in the flora).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=bruggen1973a |text=Bruggen, H. W. E. van. 1973. Revision of the genus Aponogeton (Aponogetonaceae): VI. The species of Africa. Bull. Jard. Bot. Natl. Belg. 43: 1--2, 193--233. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=bruggen1985a |text=Bruggen, H. W. E. van. 1985. Monograph of the Genus Aponogeton (Aponogetonaceae). Stuttgart. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Aponogetonaceae |author=C. Barre Hellquist;Robert R. Haynes |authority=J. Agardh |rank=family |parent rank= |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Aponogetonaceae |illustrator=John Myers |illustration copyright=Flora of North America Association |distribution=North America;s Africa;and tropical regions of Eastern Hemisphere. |reference=bruggen1973a;bruggen1985a |publication title= |publication year= |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_287.xml }}[[Category:Treatment]]
{{#ask: [[Plate of taxon::<q>[[Category:Aponogetonaceae]]</q>]] | ?Plate of taxon.Taxon family=Family | ?Plate of taxon=Taxon | ?Plate of taxon.Illustrator | format=gallery | limit=3 }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aptenia |accepted_authority=N. E. Brown |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gard. Chron., ser. |place=3, 78: 412. 1925 |year=1925 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Aizoaceae;Aptenia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Aizoaceae]]
genus[[Aptenia]]
|etymology=Greek a- , not, and pt enos, winged, in reference to the lack of wings on the capsules |volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 77 |treatment_page=page 83 }}Subshrubs, succulent, minutely papillate to smooth, glabrous. Roots fibrous, sometimes thick and fleshy. Stems prostrate or climbing, green. Leaves cauline, opposite [alternate], petiolate, those of each pair equal; stipules absent; blade cordate [lanceolate], flat, margins entire. Inflorescences axillary [terminal], flowers solitary or in few-flowered clusters, sessile or peduncled; bracts absent. Flowers showy, campanulate, 1 cm diam.; hypanthium conic; calyx lobes 4, unequal, 2 larger and leaflike, 2 green, tapered; petals (including petaloid staminodia) 140, connate proximally, white, cream, yellow, or pink to purple; nectary absent; stamens 80, arising from hypanthium; pistil 4-carpellate; ovary inferior, 4-loculed; placentation axile; styles absent; stigmas 4, linear. Fruits capsules, hygroscopic, obconic; valves 4; valve lids and wings absent. Seeds 800, brownish black, flat, tuberculate; arils absent.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Europe;Africa;Australia. |introduced=true |discussion=

Species 2 (1 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aptenia |author=Nancy J. Vivrette |authority=N. E. Brown |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Aizoaceae |distribution=Europe;Africa;Australia. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Gard. Chron., ser. |publication year=1925 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_172.xml |genus=Aptenia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aizoaceae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aptenia cordifolia |accepted_authority=(Linnaeus f.) Schwantes |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gartenflora, |place=57: 69. 1928 |year=1928 }} |common_names=Baby sun-rose |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Mesembryanthemum cordifolium |authority=Linnaeus f. |rank=species |publication_title=Suppl. Pl., |publication_place=260. 1782 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Aizoaceae;Aptenia;Aptenia cordifolia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Aizoaceae]]
genus[[Aptenia]]
species[[Aptenia cordifolia]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 83 |treatment_page=page 84 }}Plants short-lived. Stems 3–6 dm; internodes 1–5 cm; often rooting at nodes. Leaf blades 1–3 × 0.5–5 cm, minutely papillate, appearing smooth. Inflorescences solitary flowers; axillary pedicel 8–15 mm. Flowers: hypanthium 6–7 mm; calyx lobes 2–5 mm; petals 80, reflexed, pink to purple (red in hybrid cultivar “Red Apple”), 3–4 mm; staminodia 50, erect, white, 3 mm. Capsules 13–15 mm. 2n = 18.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Disturbed places, coastal bluffs, margins of coastal wetlands, 0-100 m |distribution=Calif.;Oreg.;Europe (British Isles);Africa;Australia. |introduced=true |discussion=

The flowers of Aptenia cordifolia open during the bright hours of the day.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aptenia cordifolia |authority=(Linnaeus f.) Schwantes |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Mesembryanthemum cordifolium |family=Aizoaceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Disturbed places, coastal bluffs, margins of coastal wetlands, 0-100 m |distribution=Calif.;Oreg.;Europe (British Isles);Africa;Australia. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Gartenflora, |publication year=1928 |special status=Introduced;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_173.xml |genus=Aptenia |species=Aptenia cordifolia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aptenia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apteria |accepted_authority=Nuttall |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=J. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia |place=7: 64. 1834 |year=1834 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Burmanniaceae;Apteria |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Burmanniaceae]]
genus[[Apteria]]
|etymology=Greek a, without, and pteron, wing |volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 487 |treatment_page=page 488 }}Plants possibly perennial, mycotrophic, not green. Rhizomes present. Roots filiform. Stems sometimes branched. Leaves cauline, white or purplish, scalelike to lanceolate. Inflorescences 2–6-flowered racemose cymes or flowers solitary; floral bracts not imbricate. Flowers erect to nodding, neither ribbed nor winged; perianth persistent and rolled in fruit; annulus absent; stamens 3, proximal to inner perianth lobes, sessile; ovary 1-locular; placentation parietal; pedicel 4–12(–18) mm. Capsules broadly ellipsoid; dehiscence longitudinal by valves, leaving 3 placental ribs.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Tropical North America;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America. |discussion=

Species 1.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Apteria |authority=Nuttall |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Burmanniaceae |distribution=Tropical North America;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America. |reference=None |publication title=J. Acad. Nat. Sci. Philadelphia |publication year=1834 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_1013.xml |genus=Apteria }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Burmanniaceae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Apteria aphylla |accepted_authority=(Nuttall) Barnhart ex Small |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. S.E. U.S., |place=309. 1903 |year=1903 }} |common_names=Nodding-nixie |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Lobelia aphylla |authority=Nuttall |rank=species |publication_title=Amer. J. Sci. Arts |publication_place=5: 297. 1822 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Apteria setacea |authority=Nuttall |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Burmanniaceae;Apteria;Apteria aphylla |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Burmanniaceae]]
genus[[Apteria]]
species[[Apteria aphylla]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 488 |treatment_page=page 489 }}Stems often purplish, 3–27 cm. Leaves often purplish, 1.5–4 × 0.5–1.5 mm. Inflorescences: floral bracts 2–4 mm. Flowers 8–14 mm; perianth purple or white with purplish longitudinal stripes inside throat and purplish perianth lobes; lobes erect, incurved and converging but not connate; outer lobes ovate to triangular, 1.5–4 mm; inner lobes lanceolate, ± as long as outer. Capsules 3–6 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Bogs, alluvial and upland rich woods |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;Tex.;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America (to Peru;Paraguay;Bolivia;Brazil). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Apteria aphylla |authority=(Nuttall) Barnhart ex Small |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Apteria setacea |basionyms=Lobelia aphylla |family=Burmanniaceae |phenology=Flowering late summer–fall. |habitat=Bogs, alluvial and upland rich woods |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss.;Tex.;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America (to Peru;Paraguay;Bolivia;Brazil). |reference=None |publication title=Fl. S.E. U.S., |publication year=1903 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_1014.xml |genus=Apteria |species=Apteria aphylla }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Apteria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 533. 175 }}, {{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. Pl. ed. |place=5, 237. 1754 |year=1754 }} |common_names=Columbine;ancolie |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
|etymology=derivation disputed; possibly Greek aqua, water, and legere, to draw or collect, because of the wet habitat of some species or quantity of liquid nectar borne in spurs, or Latin aquila, eagle, because of similarity in shape of curved spurs of some European species to an eagle's talons |volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, perennial, from slender woody rhizomes. Leaves basal and cauline, proximal leaves petiolate, distal leaves sessile; cauline leaves alternate. Leaf blade 1-3×-ternately compound, leaflets lobed or parted, margins crenate. Inflorescences terminal, 1-10-flowered cymes or solitary flowers, to 30 cm; bracts leaflike, not forming involucre. Flowers bisexual, radially symmetric; sepals not persistent in fruit, 5, white to blue, yellow, or red, plane, narrowly ovate to oblong-lanceolate, short-clawed, 7-51 mm; petals 5, distinct, white to blue, yellow, or red, oblong to rounded or spatulate blade, 0-30 mm, base backward-pointing tubular spur, apex plane; nectary in ± enlarged tip of spur; stamens many; filaments filiform; scalelike staminodes usually present between stamens and pistils; pistils 5-10, simple; ovules many per pistil; beak present. Fruits follicles, aggregate, sessile, cylindric, sides prominently veined; beak terminal, straight, 3-26 mm. Seeds black, obovoid, smooth. x = 7.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Circumboreal. |discussion=

Species ca. 70 (21 in the flora).

Species of Aquilegia are polymorphic and difficult to define adequately. Some of the variability is because of introgressive hybridization. Even distantly related species of columbine are often freely interfertile, and many cases of natural hybridization and introgression are known from North America. Only the most important are mentioned below. In arid areas Aquilegia species tend to form small populations often completely isolated from one another. This leads to local fixation of genes and therefore increased variability in species such as A. micrantha and A. desertorum. In addition, populations with spurless petals are occasionally found in many species.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=munz1946a |text=Munz, P. A. 1946. The cultivated and wild columbines. Gentes Herb. 7: 1-150. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=payson1918a |text=Payson, E. B. 1918. The North American species of Aquilegia. Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. 20: 133-157. }} }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia barnebyi |accepted_authority=Munz |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Leafl. W. Bot. |place=5: 177-178. 1949 |year=1949 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia barnebyi |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia barnebyi]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 30-80 cm. Basal leaves 2-3×-ternately compound, 5-30 cm, much shorter than stems; leaflets to 8-20 mm, glaucous on both sides, not viscid; primary petiolules 17-34 mm (leaflets not crowded), glabrous. Flowers erect or nodding; sepals perpendicular to floral axis, pink, ovate-lanceolate to elliptic, 10-18 × 5-7 mm, apex acute or acuminate; petals: spurs pink, straight, ± parallel, 14-27 mm, stout proximally, slender distally, evenly tapered from base, blades yellow or cream, oblong, 6-10 × 4-6 mm; stamens 11-16 mm. Follicles 18-25 mm; beak 8-12 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer (Jun–Jul). |habitat=Cliff walls and talus slopes, usually on shale |elevation=1500-2600 m |distribution=Colo.;Utah. |discussion=

Aquilegia barnebyi is endemic to the Green River drainage. It is very similar to A. micrantha, and intermediate plants are found in Colorado.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aquilegia barnebyi |authority=Munz |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Ranunculaceae |phenology=Flowering summer (Jun–Jul). |habitat=Cliff walls and talus slopes, usually on shale |elevation=1500-2600 m |distribution=Colo.;Utah. |reference=None |publication title=Leafl. W. Bot. |publication year=1949 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_74.xml |genus=Aquilegia |species=Aquilegia barnebyi }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aquilegia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia brevistyla |accepted_authority=Hooker |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Bor.-Amer. |place=1: 24. 1829 |year=1829 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia brevistyla |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia brevistyla]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 20-80 cm. Basal leaves 2×-ternately compound, 5-30 cm, much shorter than stems; leaflets green adaxially, to 12-44 mm, not viscid; primary petiolules 10-55 mm (leaflets not crowded), distally pilose or occasionally glabrous. Flowers nodding; sepals divergent from floral axis, blue, lanceolate or narrowly elliptic, 13-16 × 3-6 mm, apex acuminate or acute; petals: spurs blue, hooked, 5-10 mm, stout, evenly tapered from base, blades white or pale yellow, oblong, 7-10 × 3-6 mm; stamens 7-11 mm. Follicles 15-25 mm; beak 3-4 mm. 2n = 14, 16.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer (Jun–Aug). |habitat=Open woods, meadows, shores, and rock outcrops |elevation=800-3500 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.W.T.;Ont.;Sask.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont.;S.Dak.;Wyo. |discussion=

Aquilegia brevistyla has been reported from Minnesota. All Minnesota material seen, however, has been misidentified.

The chromosome number in this species needs to be reinvestigated.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aquilegia brevistyla |authority=Hooker |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Ranunculaceae |phenology=Flowering summer (Jun–Aug). |habitat=Open woods, meadows, shores, and rock outcrops |elevation=800-3500 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.W.T.;Ont.;Sask.;Yukon;Alaska;Mont.;S.Dak.;Wyo. |reference=None |publication title=Fl. Bor.-Amer. |publication year=1829 |special status=Endemic;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_220.xml |genus=Aquilegia |species=Aquilegia brevistyla }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aquilegia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia canadensis |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 533-534. 1753 |year=1753 }} |common_names=Canadian columbine;ancolie du Canada |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia australis |authority=Small |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia canadensis var. australis |authority=(Small) Munz |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia canadensis var. coccinea |authority=(Small) Munz |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia canadensis var. eminens |authority=(Greene) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia canadensis var. latiuscula |authority=(Greene) Munz |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia coccinea |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia canadensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia canadensis]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 15-90 cm. Basal leaves 2×-ternately compound, 7-30 cm, much shorter than stems; leaflets green adaxially, 17-52 mm, not viscid; primary petiolules 17-93 mm (leaflets not crowded), glabrous or pilose, sometimes somewhat viscid. Flowers pendent; sepals divergent from floral axis, red or apex green, lance-ovate to oblong-ovate, 8-18 × 3-8 mm, apex broadly acute to acuminate; petals: spurs red, straight, ± parallel to divergent, 13-25 mm, stout (at least proximally), abruptly narrowed near middle, blades pale yellow or yellow-green, oblong to rounded, 5-9 × 4-8 mm; stamens 15-23 mm. Follicles 15-31 mm; beak 10-18 mm. 2n = 14.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer (Mar–Jun). |habitat=Shaded or open woods, often around cliffs, rock outcrops, and forest edges |elevation=0-1600 m |distribution=Man.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |discussion=

P. A. Munz divided this species into five varieties, based on size of the plants, sepals, and leaflets and whether the leaves are 2-3×-ternately compound. The variation in size of these organs is not discontinuous or even bimodal, however, and I have not seen any material with 3×-ternately compound leaves. For this reason, no varieties are recognized here. The name Aquilegia canadensis var. hybrida Hooker has been misapplied to this species; the type specimen actually belongs to A. brevistyla (B. Boivin 1953).

Aquilegia canadensis has also been reported from New Brunswick, but the specimen has been destroyed and the species has never been recollected in the province.

Native Americans prepare infusions from various parts of plants of Aquilegia canadensis to treat heart trouble, kidney problems, headaches, bladder problems, and fever, and as a wash for poison ivy; pulverized seeds were used as love charms; and a compound was used to detect bewitchment (D. E. Moerman 1986).

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia chaplinei |accepted_authority=Standley ex Payson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |place=20: 156-157. 1918 |year=1918 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia chrysantha var. chaplinei |authority=(Payson) E. J. Lott |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia chaplinei |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia chaplinei]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 20-50 cm. Basal leaves 2-3×-ternately compound, 7-25 cm, much shorter than stems; leaflets to 9-19 mm, not viscid, sometimes glaucous adaxially; primary petiolules to 10-95 mm (leaflets not crowded), glabrous or sparsely pilose. Flowers suberect to inclined; sepals perpendicular to floral axis, pale yellow, broadly lanceolate, 9-19 × 4-6 mm, apex obtuse to acuminate; petals: spurs yellow, straight, ± parallel or divergent, 30-40 mm, slender, evenly tapered from base, blades pale yellow, oblong, 7-14 × 5-6 mm; stamens 10-19 mm. Follicles 18-22 mm; beak 15-18 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer (Jul–Aug). |habitat=Rocky places in canyons, mostly along streams |elevation=1900 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex. |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Aquilegia chaplinei is endemic to the Guadalupe Mountains.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aquilegia chaplinei |authority=Standley ex Payson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Aquilegia chrysantha var. chaplinei |basionyms= |family=Ranunculaceae |phenology=Flowering summer (Jul–Aug). |habitat=Rocky places in canyons, mostly along streams |elevation=1900 m |distribution=N.Mex.;Tex. |reference=None |publication title=Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. |publication year=1918 |special status=Conservation concern;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V3/V3_1058.xml |genus=Aquilegia |species=Aquilegia chaplinei }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aquilegia]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia chrysantha |accepted_authority=A. Gray |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |place=8: 621. 1873 |year=1873 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Aquilegia chrysantha var. rydbergii |authority=Munz |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia chrysantha |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia chrysantha]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 30-120 cm. Basal leaves 2-3×-ternately compound, 9-45 cm, much shorter than stems; leaflets green adaxially, to 11-55 mm, not viscid; primary petiolules 20-50 mm (leaflets not crowded), glabrous or distally pilose. Flowers erect; sepals perpendicular to floral axis, yellow, lanceolate to ovate-lanceolate, 20-36 × 5-10 mm, apex narrowly acute or acuminate; petals: spurs yellow, straight, ± parallel or divergent, 42-65 mm, slender, evenly tapered from base, blades yellow, oblong, 13-23 × 6-15 mm; stamens 12-25 mm. Follicles 18-30 mm; beak 10-18 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer (Apr–Sep). |habitat=Damp places in canyons |elevation=1000-3500 m |distribution=Ariz.;Colo.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;nw Mexico. |discussion=

Colorado populations supposedly having spurs only 35-40 mm have been called Aquilegia chrysantha var. rydbergii. Material seen from this area falls within the normal range of variation of the species. Populations intermediate between A. chrysantha and A. coerulea var. pinetorum occur in northern Arizona (M. Butterwick et al. 1991).

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia coerulea |accepted_authority=E. James |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Account Exped. Pittsburgh |place=2: 15. 1823 |year=1823 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia coerulea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia coerulea]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Stems 15-80 cm. Basal leaves (1-)2(-3)×-ternately compound, 9-37 cm, much shorter than stems; leaflets green adaxially, to 13-42(-61) mm, not viscid; primary petiolules (10-)20-70 mm (leaflets not crowded), glabrous or occasionally pilose. Flowers erect; sepals perpendicular to floral axis, white, blue, or sometimes pink, elliptic-ovate to lance-ovate, 26-51 × 8-23 mm, apex obtuse to acute or acuminate; petals: spurs white, blue, or sometimes pink, straight, ± parallel or divergent, 28-72 mm, slender, evenly tapered from base, blades white, oblong or spatulate, 13-28 × 5-14 mm; stamens 13-24 mm. Follicles 20-30 mm; beak 8-12 mm.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Ariz.;Colo.;Idaho;Mont.;N.Mex.;Nev.;Utah;Wyo.;Mexico. |discussion=

Varieties 4 (4 in the flora).

Aquilegia coerulea shows considerable geographic variation in flower color and in size of different floral organs, reflecting adaptation to different pollinators in different parts of its range (R. B. Miller 1981). Four weakly differentiated varieties are recognized.

Aquilegia coerulea var. coerulea and A. coerulea var. ochroleuca intergrade to some extent; northwestern populations of var. coerulea often contain individuals with pale flowers, and eastern populations of var. ochroleuca often contain blue-flowered plants.

The Gosivte tribe chewed the seeds of Aquilegia coerulea or used an infusion made from the roots to treat abdominal pains or as a panacea (D. E. Moerman 1986).

Most authors have spelled the epithet "caerulea"; "coerulea" is the original spelling.

Columbine (as Aquilegia caerulea) is the state flower of Colorado.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=miller1981a |text=Miller, R. B. 1981. Hawkmoths and the geographic patterns of floral variation in Aquilegia caerulea. Evolution 35: 763-774. }} }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aquilegia coerulea var. pinetorum |accepted_authority=(Tidestrom) Payson ex Kearney & Peebles |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Pl. Ferns Ariz., |place=318. 1942 |year=1942 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Aquilegia pinetorum |authority=Tidestrom |rank=species |publication_title=Amer. Midl. Naturalist |publication_place=1: 166-167. 1910 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Ranunculaceae;Aquilegia;Aquilegia coerulea;Aquilegia coerulea var. pinetorum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Ranunculaceae]]
genus[[Aquilegia]]
species[[Aquilegia coerulea]]
variety[[Aquilegia coerulea var. pinetorum]]
|volume=Volume 3 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Leaves 2-3×-ternately compound. Flowers: sepals white, pale blue, or pink, (22-)29-51 mm; petals: spurs 43-72 mm, blades 20-28 mm; stamens 17-24 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–summer (May–Sep). |habitat=Rocky slopes or near streams, in open woodland or herbland |elevation=1800-3400 m |distribution=Ariz.;Utah. |discussion=

Aquilegia coerulea var. pinetorum is very close to A. coerulea var. ochroleuca; leaf differences given by P. A. Munz (1946) do not hold up. The varieties may be reliably distinguished if data on variation in the whole population are available (mean spur length 40-48 mm in populations of A. coerulea var. ochroleuca, 50-58 mm in populations of A. coerulea var. pinetorum), but the range for individual flowers overlaps somewhat.
